Running title reads: The first part of sir Iohn Old-castle.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.p: The first part Of the true and honorable historie, of the life of Sir John Old-castle, the good Lord Cobham. As it hath been lately acted by the right honorable the Earle of Notingham Lord high Admirall of England his seruants.
LONDON Printed by V.S. for Thomas Pauier, and are to be solde at his shop at the signe of the Catte and Parrots neere the Exchange. 1600.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: Vpon the Argument we haue in hand,
May breede suspence, and wrongfully disturbe
The peacefull quiet of your setled thoughts:
To stop which scruple, let this briefe suffise.
It is no pamperd glutton we present,
Nor aged Councellor to youthfull sinne,
But one, whose vertue shone aboue the rest,
A valiant Martyr, and a vertuous peere,
In whose true faith and loyaltie exprest
Vnto his soveraigne, and his countries weale:
We striue to pay that tribute of our Loue,
Your fauours merite, let faire Truth be grac'te,
Since forg'de inuention former time defac'te.

div.head: The true and honorable Historie, of the life of Sir Iohn Oldcastle, the good Lord Cobham.
div.stage: In the fight, enter the Sheriffe and two of his men.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.l: MY Lords, I charge ye in his Highnesse name,
To keepe the peace, you, and your followers.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Good M. Sheriffe, look vnto your self.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Do so, for we haue other businesse.

div.stage: Proffer to fight againe

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Will ye disturbe the Iudges, and the Assise?
Heare the Kings proclamation ye were best.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Hold then, lets heare it.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: But be briefe, ye were best.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Cossone, make shorter O, or shall marre your Yes.

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: What, has her nothing to say but O yes?

sp.speaker: Bay.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: O nay, pye Cosse plut downe with her, down with her,
A Pawesse a Pawesse.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert, and downe with Powesse.

div.stage: Helter skelter againe.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Hold, in the Kings name, hold.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Downe e tha ka naues name, downe.

div.stage: In this fight, the Bailiffe is knocked downe, and the Sheriffe and the other runne away.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Powesse, I thinke thy Welsh and thou do smart.

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: Herbert, I thinke my sword came neere thy heart.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Thy hearts best bloud shall pay the losse of mine.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: A Pawesse a Pawesse.

div.stage: As they are lifting their weapons, enter the Maior of Hereford, and his Officers and Townes men with clubbes.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: My Lords, as you are liege men to the Crowne,
True noblemen, and subiects to the King,
Attend his Highnesse proclamation,
Commaunded by the Iudges of Assise,
For keeping peace at this assemblie.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Good M. Maior of Hereford be briefe.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.l: Serieant, without the ceremonie of O yes.
Pronounce alowd the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Kings Iustices, perceiuing what publique mischiefe may ensue this priuate quarrel in his maiesties name do straightly charge and commaund all persons, of what degree soeuer, to depart this cittie of Hereford, except such as are bound to giue attendance at this Assise, and that no man presume to weare any weapon, especially welsh-hookes, forrest billes.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Haw, no pill nor wells hoog? ha?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Peace, and heare the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And that the Lord Powesse do presently disperse and discharge his retinue, and depart the cittie in the Kings peace, he and his followers, on paine of imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Haw? pud her Lord Pawesse in prison, A Pawes
A Pawesse, cossone liue and tie with her Lord.

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: A Herbert a Herbert.

div.stage:
In this fight the Lord Herbert is wounded, and fals to the ground, the Maior and his company goe away crying clubbes, Powesse runnes away, Gough and other of Herberts faction busie themselues about Herbert: enters the two Iudges in their roabes,
the Sheriffe and his Baileffes afore them, &c.

sp.speaker: 1. Iud.
sp.p: Where's the Lord Herbert? is he hurt or slaine?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Hee's here my Lord.

sp.speaker: 2. Iud.
sp.p: How fares hid Lordshippe, friends?

sp.speaker: Gough
sp.p: Mortally wounded, speechlesse, he cannot liue.

sp.speaker: 1. Iud
sp.l: Conuay him hence, let not his wounds take ayre,
And get him dress'd with expedition, Ex. Herb. & Gough
M. Maior of Hereford M Shriue o'th shire,
Commit Lord Powesse to safe custodie,
To answer the disturbance of the peace,
Lord Herberts perill, and his high contempt
Of vs, and you the Kings commissioners,
See it be done with care and diligence.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Please it your Lordship, my Lord Powesse is gone,
Past all recouery.

sp.speaker: 2. Iud.
sp.l: Yet let search be made,
To apprehend his followers that are left.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: There are some of them, sirs, lay hold on them,

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Of vs, and why? what has her done I pray you?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Disarme them Bailiffes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Officers assist.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Heare you Lor shudge, what resson is for this?

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Cosson pe puse for fighting for our Lord?

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.p: Away with them.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Harg you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Gough my Lorde Herberts man's a shitten knaue, Both at once al this

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Ise liue and tie in good quarrell.

sp.speaker: Owen
sp.p: Pray you do shustice, let awl be preson.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Prison no,
Lord shudge I wooll giue you pale, good suerty.

sp.speaker: 2. Iudge
sp.p: What Bale? what suerties?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Her coozin ap Ries, ap Euan, ap Morrice, ap Morgan, ap Lluellyn, ap Madoc, ap Meredith, ap Griffen, ap Dauy, ap Owen ap Shinken Shones.

sp.speaker: 2 Iudge.
sp.p: Two of the most, sufficient are ynow,

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: And't please your Lordship these are al but one.

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.l: To Iayle with them, and the Lord Herberts men,
Weele talke with them, when the Assise is done, Exeunt.
Riotous, audacious, and vnruly Groomes,
Must we be forced to come from the Bench,
To quiet brawles, which euery Constable
In other ciuill places can suppresse?

sp.speaker: 2. Iudge
sp.p: What was the quarrel that causde all this stirre?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: About religion (as I heard) my Lord.
Lord Powesse detracted from the power of Rome,
Affirming Wickliffes doctrine to be true,
And Romes erroneous: hot reply was made
By the lord Herbert, they were traytors all
That would maintaine it: Powesse answered,
They were as true, as noble, and as wise
As he, that would defend it with their liues,
He namde for instance sir Iohn Old-castle
The Lord Cobham: Herbert replide againe,
He, thou, and all are traitors that so hold.
The he was giuen, the seuerall factions drawne,
And so enragde, that we could not appease it.

sp.speaker: 1. Iudge
sp.l: This case concernes the Kings prerogatiue,
And's dangerous to the State and common wealth.
Gentlemen, Iustices, master Maior, and master Shrieue,
It doth behoue vs all, and each of vs
In generall and particular, to haue care
For the suppressing of all mutinies,
And all assemblies, except souldiers musters
For the Kings preparation into France.
We heare of secret conuenticles made,
And there is doubt of some conspiracies,
Which may breake out into rebellious armes
When the King's gone, perchance before he go:
Note as an instance, this one perillous fray,
What factions might haue growne on either part,
To the destruction of the King and Realme,
Yet, in my conscience, sir Iohn Old-castle
Innocent of it, onely his name was vsde.
We therefore from his Highnesse giue this charge.
You maister Maior, looke to your citizens,
You maister Sherife vnto your shire, and you
As Iustices in euery ones precinct
There be no meetings. When the vulgar sort
Sit on their Ale-bench, with their cups and kannes,
Matters of state be not their common talke,
Nor pure religion by their lips prophande.
Let vs returne vnto the Bench againe,
And there examine further of this fray. Enter a Baily and a Serieant

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Sirs, haue ye taken the lord Powesse yet?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: No, nor heard of him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No, hee's gone farre enough.

sp.speaker: 2. Iu.
sp.p: They that are left behind, shall answer all. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Suffolke, Bishop of Rochester, Butler, parson of Wrotham.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: Now my lord Bishop, take free liberty
To speake your minde: what is your sute to vs?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My noble Lord, no more than what you know,
And haue bin oftentimes inuested with:
Grieuous complaints haue past betweene the lippes
Of enuious persons to vpbraide the Cleargy,
Some carping at the liuings which we haue,
And others spurning at the ceremonies
That are of auncient custome in the church.
Amongst the which, Lord Cobham is a chiefe:
What inconuenience may proceede hereof,
Both to the King and to the common wealth,
May easily be discernd, when like a frensie
This innouation shall possesse their mindes.
These vpstarts will haue followers to vphold
Their damnd opinion, more than Harry shall
To vndergoe his quarrell gainst the French.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: What proofe is there against them to be had,
That what you say the law may iustifie?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: They giue themselues the name of Protestants,
And meete in fields and solitary groues.

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.l: Was euer heard (my Lord) the like til now?
That theeues and rebells, sbloud heretikes,
Playne heretikes, Ile stand toote to their teeth,
Should haue to colour, their vile practises,
A title of such worth, as Protestant? enter one wyth a letter.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: O but you must not sweare, it ill becomes
One of your coate, to rappe out bloudy oathes.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Pardon him good my Lord, it is his zeale,
An honest country prelate, who laments
To see such foule disorder in the church.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.l: Theres one they call him Sir Iohn Old-castle,
He has not his name for naught: for like a castle
Doth he encompasse them within his walls,
But till that castle be subuerted quite,
We ne're shall be at quiet in the realme.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: That is our sute, my Lord, that he be tane,
And brought in question for his heresie,
Beside, two letters brought me out of Wales,
Wherin my Lord Herford writes to me,
What tumult and sedition was begun,
About the Lord Cobham, at the Sises there,
For they had much ado to calme the rage,
And that the valiant Herbert is there slaine.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: A fire that must be quencht; wel, say no more,
The King anon goes to the counsell chamber,
There to debate of matters touching France:
As he doth passe by, Ile informe his grace
Concerning your petition: Master Butler,
If I forget, do you remember me,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will my Lord. Offer him a purse.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Not for a recompence,
But as a token of our loue to you,
By me my Lords of the cleargie do present
This purse, and in it full a thousand Angells,
Praying your Lordship to accept their gift.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: I thanke them, my Lord Bishop, for their loue,
But will not take their mony, if you please
To giue it to this gentleman, you may.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Sir, then we craue your furtherance herein.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The best I can my Lord of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Nay, pray ye take it, trust me but you shal,

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Were ye all three vpon New Market heath,
You should not neede straine curtsie who should ha'te,
Sir Iohn would quickely rid ye of that care.

sp.speaker: Suf
sp.l: The King is comming, feare ye not my Lord,
The very first thing I will breake with him,
Shal be about your matter. Enter K. Harry and Huntington in talke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke,
Was it not saide the Cleargy did refuse
To lend vs mony toward our warres in France?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: It was my Lord, but very wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I know it was, for Huntington here tells me,
They haue bin very bountifull of late.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: And still they vow my gracious Lord to be so,
Hoping your maiestie will thinke of them,
As of your louing subiects, and suppresse
All such malitious errors as begin
To spot their calling, and disturb the church.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: God else forbid: why Suffolke, is there
Any new rupture to disquiet them?

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: No new my Lord, the old is great enough,
And so increasing as if not cut downe,
Will breede a scandale to your royall state,
And set your Kingdome quickely in an vproare,
The Kentish knight Lord Cobham, in despight
Of any law, or spirituall discipline,
Maintaines this vpstart new religion still,
And diuers great assemblies by his meanes
And priuate quarrells, are commenst abroad,
As by this letter more at large my liege,
Is made apparant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We do find it here,
There was in Wales a certaine fray of late,
Betweene two noblemen, but what of this?
Followes it straight Lord Cobham must be he
Did cause the same? I dare be sworne (good knight)
He neuer dreampt of any such contention.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: But in his name the quarrell did begin,
About the opinion which he held (my hege.)

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How if it did? was either he in place,
To take part with them, or abette them in it?
If brabling fellowes, whose in kindled bloud,
Seethes in their fiery vaines, will needes go fight,
Making their quarrells of some words that passt,
Either of you, or you, amongst their cuppes,
Is the fault yours, or are they guiltie of it?

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.l: With pardon of your Highnesse (my dread lord)
Such little sparkes neglected, may in time
Grow to a mighty flame: but thats not all,
He doth beside maintaine a strange religion,
And will not be compelld to come to masse.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: We do beseech you therefore gracious prince,
Without offence vnto your maiesty
We may be bold to vse authoritie.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: To summon him vnto the Arches,
Where such offences haue their punishment.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: To answere personally, is that your meaning?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: It is, my lord.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: How if he appeale?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.p: He cannot (my Lord) in such a case as this.

sp.speaker: Suffolke
sp.p: Not where Religion is the plea, my lord.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.l: I tooke it alwayes, that our selfe stoode out,
As a sufficient refuge, vnto whome
Not any but might lawfully appeale.
But weele not argue now vpon that poynt:
For sir Iohn Old-castle whom you accuse,
Let me intreate you to dispence awhile
With your high title of preheminence. in scorne.
Report did neuer yet condemne him so,
But he hath alwayes beene reputed loyall:
And in my knowledge I can say thus much,
That he is vertuous, wise, and honourable:
If any way his conscience be seduc'de,
To wauer in his faith: Ile send for him,
And schoole him priuately, if that serue not,
Then afterward you may proceede against him.
Butler, be you the messenger for vs,
And will him presently repaire to court. exeunt.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: How now my lord, why stand you discontent?
In sooth, me thinkes the King hath well decreed.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Yea, yea, sir Iohn, if he would keepe his word,
But I perceiue he fauours him so much,
As this will be to small effect, I feare.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Why then Ile tell you what y'are best to do:
If you suspect the King will be but cold
In reprehending him, send you a processe too
To serue vpon him: so you may be sure
To make him answer't, howsoere it fall.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: And well remembred, I will haue it so,
A Sumner shall be sent about it strait Exit.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Yea, doe so, in the meane space this remaines
For kinde sir Iohn of Wrotham honest Iacke.
Me thinkes the purse of gold the Bishop gaue,
Made a good shew, it had a tempting looke,
Beshrew me, but my fingers ends do itch
To be vpon those rudduks: well, tis thus:
I am not as the worlde does take me for:
If euer woolfe were cloathed in sheepes coate,
Then I am he, olde huddle and twang, yfaith,
A priest in shew, but in plaine termes, a theefe,
Yet let me tell you too, an honest theefe.
One that will take it where it may besp.
And spend it freely in good fellowship.
I haue as many shapes as Proteus had,
That still when any villany is done,
There may be none suspect it was sir Iohn.
Besides, to comfort me, for whats this life,
Except the crabbed bitternes thereof
Be sweetened now and then with lechery?
I haue my Doll, my concubine as t'were,
To frollicke with, a lusty bounsing gerle.
But whilst I loyter here the gold, may scape,
And that must not be so, it is mine owne,
Therefore Ile meete him on his way to court,
And shriue him of it: there will be the sport. Exit.

div.stage: Enter three or foure poore people, some souldiers, some old men.

sp.l: God help, God help, there's law for punishing,
But theres no law for our necessity:
There be more stockes to set poore soldiers in,
Than there be houses to releeue them at.

sp.speaker: Old man
sp.l: Faith, housekeeping decayes in euery place,
Euen as Saint Peter writ, still worse and worse

sp.p: Maister maior of Rochester has giuen commaundement, that none shall goe abroade out of the parish, and they haue set an order downe forsooth, what euery poore housholder must giue towards our reliefe: where there be some ceased I may say to you, had almost as much neede to beg as we.
It is a hard world the while.

sp.speaker: Old man
sp.p: If a poore man come to a doore to aske for Gods sake, they aske him for a licence, or a certificate from a Iustice.
Faith we haue none, but what we beare vppon our bodies, our maimed limbs, God help vs.
And yet, as lame as I am, Ile with the king into France, if I can crawle but a ship-boorde, I hadde rather be slaine in France, than starue in England.

sp.speaker: Olde man.
sp.p:
Ha, were I but as lusty as I was at the battell of Shrewsbury, I would not doe as I do: but we are now come to the good lord Cobhams, to the best man to the poore that
is in all Kent.
God blesse him, there be but few such.

div.stage: Enter Lord Cobham with Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Thou peeuish froward man, what wouldst thou haue?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: This pride, this pride, brings all to beggarie,
I seru'de your father, and your grandfather,
Shew me such two men now: no, no,
Your backes, your backes, the diuell and pride,
Has cut the throate of all good housekeeping,
They were the best Yeomens masters, that
Euer were in England.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Yea, except thou haue a crue of seely knaues,
And sturdy rogues, still feeding at my gate,
There is no hospitalitie with thee.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: They may sit at the gate well enough, but the diuell of any thing you giue them, except they will eate stones.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Tis long then of such hungry knaues as you, pointing to the beggars
Yea sir, heres your retinue, your guests be come,
They know their howers I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: God blesse your honour, God saue the good Lord Cobham, and all his house,

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Good your honour, bestow your blessed almes,
Vpon poore men.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Now sir, here be your Almes knights.
Now are you as safe as the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: My Almes knights: nay, th'are yours,
It is a shame for you, and Ile stand too't,
Your foolish almes maintaines more vagabonds,
Then all the noblemen in Kent beside.
Out you rogues, you knaues, worke for your liuings,
Alas poore men, O Lord, they may beg their hearts out,
Theres no more charitie amongst men,
Then amongst so many mastiffe dogges,
What make you here, you needy knaues?
Away, away, you villaines.

sp.speaker: 2. soul.
sp.p: I beseech you sit, be good to vs.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Nay, nay, they know thee well enough, I thinke that all the beggars in this land are thy acquaintance, goe bestowe your almes, none will controule you sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What should I giue them? you are growne so beggarly, you haue scarce a bitte of breade to giue at your doore: you talke of your religion so long, that you haue banished charitie from amongst you, a man may make a flaxe shop in your kitchin chimnies, for any fire there is stirring.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: If thou wilt giue them nothing, send them hence, let them not stand here staruing in the colde.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who I driue them hence? if I driue poore men from your doore, Ile be hangd, I know not what I may come to my selfe: yea, God help you poore knaues, ye see the world yfaith, well, you had a mother: well, God be with thee good Lady, thy soule's at rest: she gaue more in shirts and smocks to poore children, then you spend in your house, & yet you liue a beggar too.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Euen the worst deede that ere my mother did, was in releeuing such a foole as thou.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Yea, yea, I am a foole still, with all your wit you will die a beggar, go too.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: Go you olde foole, giue the poore people something, go in poore men into the inner court, and take such alms as there is to be had.

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.p: God blesse your honor.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Hang you roags, hang you, theres nothing but misery amongst you, you feare no law you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Olde man
sp.p: God blesse you good maister Rafe, God saue your life, you are good to the poore still.

div.stage: Enter the Lord Powes disguised, and shrowde himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What fellow's yonder comes along the groue?
Few passengers there be that know this way:
Me thinkes he stops as though he stayd for me,
And meant to shrowd himselfe amongst the bushes.
I know the Cleargie hate me to the death,
And my religion gets me many foes:
And this may be some desperate rogue,
Subornd to worke me mischiefe: As it
Pleaseth God, if he come toward me, sure
Ile stay his comming, be he but one man,
What soere he be: The Lord Powis comes on.
I haue beene well acquainted with that face.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: Well met my honorable lord and friend.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: You are welcome sir, what ere you be,
But of this sodaine sir, I do not know you.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: I am one that wisheth well vnto your honor,
My name is Powes, an olde friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My honorable lord, and worthy friend,
What makes your lordship thus alone in Kent,
And thus disguised in this strange attire?

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: My Lord, an vnexpected accident,
Hath at this time inforc'de me to these parts:
And thus it hapt, not yet ful fiue dayes since,
Now at the last Assise at Hereford,
It chanst that the lord Herbert and my selfe,
Mongst other things, discoursing at the table,
To fall in speech about some certaine points
Of Wickcliffes doctrine, gainst the papacie,
And the religion catholique, maintaind
Through the most part of Europe at this day.
This wilfull teasty lord stucke not to say,
That Wickcliffe was a knaue, a schismatike,
His doctrine diuelish and hereticall,
And what soere he was maintaind the same,
was traitor both to God and to his country.
Being moued at his peremptory speech,
I told him, some maintained those opinions,
Men, and truer subiects then lord Herbert was:
And he replying in comparisons:
Your name was vrgde, my lord, gainst his chalenge,
To be a perfect fauourer of the trueth.
And to be short, from words we fell to blowes,
Our seruants, and our tenants taking parts,
Many on both sides hurt: and for an houre
The broyle by no meanes could be pacified,
Vntill the Iudges rising from the bench,
Were in their persons forc'de to part the fray.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: I hope no man was violently slaine.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: Faith none I trust, but the lord Herberts selfe,
Who is in truth so dangerously hurt,
As it is doubted he can hardly scape.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.p: I am sory, my good lord, of these ill newes.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.l: This is the cause that driues me into Kent,
To shrowd my selfe with you so good a friend,
Vntill I heare how things do speed at home.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: Your lordship is most welcome vnto Cobham,
But I am very sory, my good lord,
My name was brought in question in this matter,
Considering I haue many enemies,
That threaten malice, and do lie in waite
To take aduantange of the smallest thing.
But you are welcome, and repose your lordship,
And keepe your selfe here secret in my house,
Vntill we heare how the lord Herbert speedes:
Here comes my man. Enter Harpoole.
Sirra, what newes?

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Yonders one maister Butler of the priuie chamber, is sent vnto you from the King.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: I pray God the lord Herbert be not dead, and the King hearing whither I am gone, hath sent for me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Comfort your selfe my lord, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Fellow, what ailes thee? doost thou quake? dost thou shake? dost thou tremble? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Peace you old foole, sirra, conuey this gentleman in the backe way, and bring the other into the walke.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: Come sir. you are welcome, if you loue my lorde.

sp.speaker: Powis
sp.p: God haue mercy gentle friend. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
I thought as much, that it would not be long before I
heard of something from the King, about this matter.

div.stage: Enter Harpoole with Maister Butler.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.l: Sir, yonder my lord walkes, you see him,
Ile haue your men into the Celler the while.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: welcome good maister Butler.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: Thankes, my good lord: his Maiestie dooth commend his loue vnto your lordship, and wils you to repaire vnto the court.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: God blesse his Highnesse, and confound his ennemies, I hope his Maiestie is well.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: In health, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: God long continue it: mee thinkes you looke as though you were not well, what ailes you sir?

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: Faith I haue had a foolish odde mischance, that angers mee: comming ouer Shooters hill, there came a fellow to me like a Sailer, and asked me money, and whilst I staide my horse to draw my purse, he takes th'aduantage of a little banck and leapes behind me, whippes my purse away, and with a sodaine ierke I know not how, threw me at least three yards out of my saddle. I neuer was so robbed in all my life.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: I am very sorie sir for your mischance, wee will send our warrant foorth, to stay such suspitious persons as shal be found, then maister Butler, we wil attend you.

sp.speaker: Butler
sp.p: I humbly thanke your lordship, I will attend you.

div.stage: Enter the Sumner.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I haue the law to warrant what I do, and though the Lord Cobham be a noble man, that dispenses not with law, I dare serue processe were a fiue noble men, though we Sumners make sometimes a mad slip in a corner with a prettie wench, a Sumner must not goe alwayes by seeing, a manne may be content to hide his eies, where he may feele his profit: well, this is my Lord Cobhams house, if I can deuise to speake with him, if not, Ile clap my citation vpon's doore, so my lord of Rochester bid me, but me thinkes here comes one of his men. Enter Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
Welcome good fellow, welcome, who wouldst thou
speake with?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: With my lord Cobham, I would speake, if thou be one of his men.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yes I am one of his men, but thou canst not speake with my lord.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: May I send to him them?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Ile tel thee that, when I know thy errand.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I will not tel my errand to thee.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Then keepe it to thy selfe, and walke like a knaue as thou camest.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I tell thee my lord keepes no knaues, sirra.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Then thou seruest him not, I beleeue, what lord is thy master?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: My lord of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: In good time, and what wouldst thou haue with my lord Cobham?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I come by vertue of a processe, to ascite him to appeare before my lord, in the court at Rochester.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: Wel, God grant me patience, I could eate this conger. My lord is not at home, therefore it were good Sumner you caried your processe backe.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Why, if he will not be spoken withall, then will I leaue it here, and see you that he take knowledge of it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Swounds you slaue, do you set vp your bills here, go to, take it downe againe, doest thou know what thou dost, dost thee know on whom thou seruest processe?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes marry doe I, Sir Iohn Old-castle Lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I am glad thou knowest him yet, and sirra dost not thou know, that the lord Cobham is a braue lord, that keepes good beefe and beere in his house, and euery day feedes a hundred poore people at's gate, and keepes a hundred tall fellowes?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Whats that to my processe?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Mary this sir, is this processe parchment?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Yes mary.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: And this seale waxe?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: If this be parchment, & this wax, eate you this parchment, and this waxe, or I will make parchment of your skinne, and beate your braines into waxe: Sirra Sumner dispatch, deuoure, sirra deuoure.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I am my lord of Rochesters Sumner, I came to do my office, and thou shalt answere it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Sirra, no railing, but betake you to your teeth, thou shalt eate no worse then thou bringst with thee, thou bringst it for my lord, and wilt thou bring my lord worse then thou wilt eate thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Sir, I brought it not my lord to eate.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: O do you sir me now, all's one for that, but ile make you eate it, for bringing it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I cannot eate it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Can you not? sbould ile beate you vntil you haue a stomacke. he beates him.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O hold, hold, good master seruing-man, I will eate it.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Be champping, be chawing sir, or Ile chaw you, you rogue, the purest of the hony.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Tough waxe, is the purest of the hony.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: O Lord sir, oh oh, he eates.
Feed, feed, wholsome rogue, wholsome.
sp.p: Cannot you like an honest Sumner walke with the diuell your brother, to fetch in your Bailiffes rents, but you must come to a noble mans house with processe? Sbloud if thy seale were as broad as the lead that couers Rochester church, thou shouldst eate it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O I am almost choaked, I am almost choaked.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who's within there? wil you shame my Lord, is there no beere in the house? Butler I say.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Heere, here. Enter Butler.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Giue him Beere. he drinkes.
There, tough old sheepskins, bare drie meate.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: O sir, let me go no further, Ile eate my word.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yea mary sir, so I meane you shall eate more then your own word, for ile make you eate all the words in the processe. Why you drab monger, cannot the secrets of al the wenches in a sheire serue your turne, but you must come hither with a citation with a poxe? Ile cite you. he has then done. A cup of sacke for the Sumner.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Here sir here.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Here slaue I drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Now if thou findst thy stomacke well, because thou shalt see my Lord keep's meate in's house, if thou wilt go in thou shalt haue a peece of beefe to thy break fast.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No I am very well good M. seruing-man, I thanke you, very well sir.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I am glad on't, then be walking towards Rochester to keepe your stomack warme: and Sumner, if I may know you disturb a good wench within this Diocesse, if I do not make thee eate her peticote, if there were four yards of Kentish cloth in't, I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: God be with you M. seruingmaan.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Farewell Sumner. Enter Constable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: God saue you M. Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Welcome Constable, welcom Constable, what news with thee?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And't please you M. Harpoole, I am to make hue to crie, for a fellow with one eie that has rob'd two Clothiers, and am to craue your hindrance, for to search all suspected places, and they say there was a woman in the company.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Hast thou bin at the Alehouse, hast thou sought there?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I durst not search sir, in my Lord Cobhams libertie, except I had some of his seruants, which are for my warrant.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: An honest Constable, an honest Constable, cal forth him that keepes the Alehouse there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ho, who's within there?

sp.speaker: Ale man
sp.p:
Who calls there, come neere a Gods name, oh is't
you M. Constable and M. Harpoole, you are welcome with all my heart, what make you here so earely this morning?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Sirra, what strangers do you lodge, there is a robbery done this morning, and we are to search for all suspected persons.

sp.speaker: Aleman.
sp.p: Gods bones, I am sory for't, yfaith sir I lodge no body but a good honest mery priest, they call him sir Iohn a Wrootham, and a handsome woman that is his neece, that he saies he has some sute in law for, and as they go vp & down to London, sometimes they lie at my house.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What, is he here in thy house now?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: She is sir, I promise you sir he is a quiet man, and because he will not trouble too many roomes, he makes the woman lie euery night at his beds feete.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Bring her forth Constable, bring her forth, let's see her, let's see her.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Dorothy, you must come downe to M. Constable.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A non forsooth. she enters.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Welcome sweete lasse, welcome.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I thank you good M. seruing-man, and master Constable also.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: A plump girle by the mas, a plump girle, ha Dol ha, wilt thou forsake the priest, and go with me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: A well said M. Harpoole, you are a merrie old man yfaith, yfaith you wil neuer be old: now by the macke, a prettie wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Ye old mad mery Constable, art thou aduis'de of that ha, well said Dol, fill some ale here.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Oh if I wist this old priest would not sticke to me, by Ioue I would ingle this old seruing-man.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Oh you old mad colt, yfaith Ile seak you: fil all the pots in the house there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh wel said M. Harpoole, you are heart of oake when all's done.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Ha Dol, thou hast a sweete paire of lippes by the masse.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Truely you are a most sweet olde man, as euer I sawe, by my troth, you haue a face, able to make any woman in loue with you.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Fill sweete Doll, Ile drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I pledge you sir, and thanke you therefore, and I pray you let it come.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: imbracing her Doll, canst thou loue me? a mad merry lasse, would to God I had neuer seene thee.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I warrant you you will not out of my thoughts this tweluemonth, truely you are as full of fauour, as a man may be. Ah these sweete grey lockes, by my troth, they are most louely.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Gods boores maister Harpoole, I will haue one busse too.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: No licking for you Constable, hand off, hand off.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Bur lady I loue kissing as wel as you.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Oh you are an od boie, you haue a wanton eie of your owne: ah you sweet sugar lipt wanton, you will winne as many womens hearts as come in your company. Enter Priest.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Doll, come hither.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Priest, she shal not.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Ile come anone, sweete loue.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Hand off, old fornicator.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Vicar, Ile sit here in spight of thee, is this fitte stuffe for a priest to carry vp and downe with him?

sp.speaker: Wrotham
sp.p: Ah sirra, dost thou not know, that a good fellow parson may haue a chappel of ease, where his parish Church is farre off?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You whooreson ston'd Vicar.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: You olde stale ruffin, you lion of Cotswold.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Swounds Vicar, Ile geld you. flies vpon him.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Keepe the Kings peace.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Ale man
sp.p: Holde, as you are men, holde, for Gods sake be quiet: put vp your weapons, you drawe not in my house.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You whooreson bawdy priest.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: You old mutton monger.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Hold sir Iohn, hold.

sp.speaker: Doll to the Priest
sp.p: I pray thee sweet heart be quiet, I was but sitting to drinke a pot of ale with him, euen as kinde a man as euer I met with.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Thou art a theefe I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Then I am but as thou hast beene in thy dayes, lets not be ashamed of our trade, the King has beene a theefe himselfe.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Come, be quiet, hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: I haue wench, here be crownes ifaith.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Come, lets be all friends then.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Well said mistris Dorothy ifaith.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Thou art the madst priest that euer I met with.

sp.speaker: Wroth.
sp.p: Giue me thy hand, thou art as good a fellow, I am a singer, a drinker, a bencher, a wencher, I can say a masse, and kisse a lasse: faith I haue a parsonage, and bicause I would not be at too much charges, this wench serues me for a sexton.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Well said mad priest, weele in and be friends, exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Roger Acton, master Bourne, master Beuerley, and William Murley the brewer of Dunstable.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Now maister Murley, I am well assurde
You know our arrant, and do like the cause,
Being a man affected as we are?

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Mary God dild ye daintie my deere, no master, good Sr Roger Acton Knight, maister Bourne, and maister Beuerley esquires, gentlemen, and iustices of the peace, no maister I, but plaine William Murly the brewer of Dunstable your honest neighbour, and your friend, if ye be men of my profession.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.p: Professed friends to Wickliffe, foes to Rome.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: Hold by me lad, leane vpon that staffe good maister Beuerley, all of a house, say your mind, say your mind.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: You know our faction now is growne so great,
Throughout the realme; that it beginnes to smoake
Into the Cleargies eies, and the Kings eares,
High time it is that we were drawne to head,
Our generall and officers appoynted.
And warres ye wot will aske great store of coine.
Able to strength our action with your purse,
You are elected for a colonell
Ouer a regiment of fifteene bands.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Fue paltrie paltrie, in and out, to and fro, be it more or lesse, vppon occasion, Lorde haue mercie vppon vs, what a world is this? Sir Roger Acton, I am but a Dunstable man, a plaine brewer, ye know: will lusty Caualiering captaines gentlemen come at my calling, goe at my bidding? Daintie my deere, theile doe a dogge of waxe, a horse of cheese, a pricke and a pudding, no, no, ye must appoint some lord or knight at least to that place.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.l: Why master Murley, you shall be a Knight:
Were you not in election to be shrieue?
Haue ye not past all offices but that?
Haue ye not wealth to make your wife a lady?
I warrant you, my lord, our Generall
Bestowes that honor on you at first sight.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.l: Mary God dild ye daintie my deare:
But tell me, who shalbe our Generall?
Wheres the lord Cobham, sir Iohn Old-castle,
That noble almes-giuer, housekeeper, vertuous,
Religious gentleman? Come to me there boies,
Come to me there.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: Why who but he shall be our Generall?

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: And shall he knight me, and make me colonell?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: My word for that, sir William Murley knight.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Fellow sir Roger Acton knight, all fellowes, I meane in armes, how strong are we? how many partners? our enemies beside the King are mightie, be it more or lesse vpon occasion, reckon our force.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: There are of vs, our friends, and followers,
Three thousand and three hundred at the least,
Of northerne lads foure thousand, beside horse,
From Kent there comes with sir Iohn Old-castle
Seauen thousand, then from London issue out,
Of maisters, seruants, strangers, prentices
Fortie odde thousands into Ficket field,
Where we appoynt our speciall randeuous.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Fue paltry paltry, in and out to and fro, Lord haue mercie vpon vs, what a world is this, wheres that Ficket fielde, sir Roger?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: Behinde saint Giles in the field neere Holborne.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Newgate, vp Holborne, S. Giles in the field, and to Tiborne, an old saw: for the day, for the day?

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.p: On friday next the foureteenth day of Ianuary.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Tyllie vallie, trust me neuer if I haue any liking of that day: fue paltry paltry, friday quoth a, dismall day, Childermasse day this yeare was friday.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Nay maister Murley, if you obserue such daies,
We make some question of your constancie,
All daies are like to men resolu'de in right.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Say Amen, and say no more, but say, and hold master Beuerley, friday next, and Ficket field, and William Murley, and his merry men shalbe al one, I haue halfe a score iades that draw my beere cartes, and euery iade shall beare a knaue, and euery knaue shall weare a iacke, and euery iacke shal haue a scull, and euery scull shal shew a speare, and euery speare shal kill a foe at Ficket field, at Ficket field, Iohn and Tom, and Dicke and Hodge, and Rafe and Robin, William & George, and all my knaues shall fight like men, at Ficket field on friday next.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.p: What summe of money meane you to disburse?

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: It may be modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely I may bring fiue hundreth pound.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Fiue hundreth man? fiue thousand's not enough,
A hundreth thousand will not pay our men
Two months together, either come preparde
Like a braue Knight, and martiall Colonell,
In glittering golde, and gallant furniture,
Bringing in coyne, a cart loade at the least,
And all your followers mounted on good horse,
Or neuer come disgracefull to vs all.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Perchance you may be chosen Treasurer,
Tenne thousand pounds the least that you can bring.

sp.speaker: Murley
sp.p: Paltry paltry, in and out and fro, vpon I haue ten thousand pound to spend, and tenne too. And rather than the Bishop shall haue his will of mee for my conscience, it shall out all. Flame and flaxe, flame and flaxe, it was gotte with water and mault, and it shal flie with fire and gunne powder. Sir Roger, a cart loade of mony til the axetree cracke, my selfe and my men in Ficket field on friday next: remember my Knighthoode, and my place: there's my hand Ile bee there. Exit.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: See what Ambition may perswade men to,
In hope of honor he will spend himselfe.

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.p: I neuer thought a Brewer halfe so rich.

sp.speaker: Beuerley
sp.l: Was neuer bankerout Brewer yet but one,
With vsing too much mault, too little water.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Thats no fault in Brewers now-adayes:
Come, away about our businesse. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter K. Harry, Suffolke, Butler, and Old-castle kneeling to the King.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.l: Tis not enough Lord Cobham to submit.
You must forsake your grosse opinion,
The Bishops find themselues much iniured,
And though for some good seruice you haue done,
We for our part are pleasde to pardon you,
Yet they will not so soone be satisfied,

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My gracious Lord vnto your Maiestie,
Next vnto my God, I owe my life,
And what is mine, either by natures gift,
Or fortunes bountie, al is at your seruice,
But for obedience to the Pope of Rome,
I owe him none, nor shall his shaueling priests
That are in England, alter my beliefe.
If out of holy Scripture they can proue,
That I am in an errour, I will yeeld,
And gladly take instruction at their hands,
But otherwise, I do beseech your grace,
My conscience may not be incroacht vpon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: We would be loath to presse our subiects bodies,
Much lesse their soules, the deere redeemed part,
Of him that is the ruler of vs all,
Yet let me counsell ye, that might command,
Do not presume to tempt them with ill words,
Nor suffer any meetings to be had
Within your house, but to the vttermost,
Disperse the flockes of this new gathering sect.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: My liege, if any breathe, that dares come forth,
And say, my life in any of these points
Deserues th'attaindor of ignoble thoughts
Here stand I, crauing no remorce at all,
But euen the vtmost rigor may be showne.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let it suffice we know your loyaltie,
What haue you there?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: A deed of clemencie,
Your Highnesse pardon for Lord Powesse life,
Which I did beg, and you my noble Lord,
Of gracious fauour did vouchsafe to grant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But yet it is not signed with our hand.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Not yet my Liege. one ready with pen and incke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The fact, you say, was done,
Not of prepensed malice, but by chance.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Vpon mine honor so, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: There is his pardon, bid him make amends, writes.
And cleanse his soule to God for his offence,
What we remit, is but the bodies scourge, Enter Bishop.
How now Lord Bishop?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Iustice dread Soueraigne.
As thou art King, so graunt I may haue iustice.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What meanes this exclamation, let vs know?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Ah my good Lord, the state's abusde,
And our decrees most shamefully prophande.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How, or by whom?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Euen by this heretike,
This Iew, this Traitor to your maiestie.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Prelate, thou liest, euen in thy greasie maw,
Or whosoeuer twits me with the name,
Of either traitor, or of heretike.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Forbeare I say, and Bishop, shew the cause
From whence this late abuse hath bin deriu'de,

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Thus mightie King, by generall consent,
A messenger was sent to cite this Lord,
To make appearance in the consistorie,
And comming to his house, a ruffian slaue,
One of his daily followers, met the man,
Who knowing him to be a parator,
Assaults him first, and after in contempt
Of vs, and our proceedings, makes him eate
The written processe, parchment, seale and all:
Whereby his maister neither was brought forth,
Nor we but scornd, for our authoritie.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: When was this done?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: At sixe a clocke this morning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And when came you to court?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Last night my Lord.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: By this it seemes, he is not guilty of it,
And you haue done him wrong t'accuse him so.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: But it was done my lord by his appointment,
Or else his man durst ne're haue bin so bold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Or else you durst be bold, to interrupt,
And fill our eares with friuolous complaints,
Is this the duetie you do beare to vs?
Was't not sufficient we did passe our word
To send for him, but you misdoubting it,
Or which is worse, intending to forestall
Our regall power, must likewise summon him?
This sauours of Ambition, not of zeale,
And rather proues, you malice his estate,
Than any way that he offends the law.
Go to, we like it not, and he your officer,
That was imployde so much amisse herein,
Had his desert for being insolent: Enter Huntington
So Cobham when you please you may depart.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I humbly bid farewell vnto my liege. Exit

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Farewell, what's the newes by Huntington?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Sir Roger Acton, and a crue, my Lord,
Of bold seditious rebels, are in Armes,
Intending reformation of Religion.
And with their Army they intend to pitch,
In Ficket field, vnlesse they be repulst.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: So nere our presence? dare they be so bold?
And will prowd warre, and eager thirst of bloud,
Whom we had thought to entertaine farre off,
Presse forth vpon vs in our natiue boundes?
Must wee be forc't to hansell our sharp blades
In England here, which we prepar'd for France?
Well, a Gods name be it, what's their number? say,
Or who's the chiefe commander of this rowt?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Their number is not knowne, as yet (my Lord)
But tis reported Sir Iohn Old-castle
Is the chiefe man, on whom they do depend.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: How, the Lord Cobham?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Yes my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: I could haue told your maiestie as much
Before he went, but that I saw your Grace
Was too much blinded by his flaterie.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: Send poast my Lord to fetch him backe againe.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Traitor vnto his country, how he smooth'de,
And seemde as innocent as Truth it selfe?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I cannot thinke it yet, he would be false,
But if he be, no matter let him go,
Weele meet both him and them vnto their wo.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: This falls out well, and at the last I hope Exeunt
To see this heretike die in a rope.

div.stage: Enter Earle of Cambridge, Lord Scroope, Gray, and Chartres the French factor.

sp.speaker: Scroop.
sp.l: Once more my Lord of Cambridge make rehersal,
How you do stand intiteled to the Crowne,
The deeper shall we print it in our mindes,
And euery man the better be resolu'de,
When he perceiues his quarrell to be iust.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Then thus Lord Scroope, sir Thomas Gray, & you
Mounsieur de Chartres, agent for the French,
This Lionell Duke of Clarence, as I said,
Third sonne of Edward (Englands King) the third
Had issue Phillip his sole daughter and heyre,
Which Phillip afterward was giuen in marriage,
To Edmund Mortimer the Earle of March,
And by him had a son cald Roger Mortimer,
Which Roger likewise had of his discent,
Edmund, Roger, Anne, and Elianor,
Two daughters and two sonnes, but those three
Dide without issue, Anne that did suruiue,
And now was left her fathers onely heyre,
My fortune was to marry, being too
By my grandfather of King Edwardes line,
So of his sirname, I am calde you know,
Richard Plantagenet, my father was,
Edward the Duke of Yorke, and son and heyre
To Edmund Langley, Edward the third's first sonne.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.l: So that it seemes your claime comes by your wife,
As lawfull heyre to Roger Mortimer,
The son of Edmund, which did marry Phillip
Daughter and heyre to Lyonell Duke of Clarence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: True, for this Harry, and his father both
Harry the first, as plainely doth appeare,
Are false intruders, and vsurp the Crowne.
For when yong Richard was at Pomfret slaine,
In him the title of prince Edward dide,
That was the eldest of king Edwards sonnes:
William of Hatfield, and their second brother,
Death in his nonage had before bereft:
So that my wife deriu'd from Lionell,
Third sonne vnto king Edward, ought proceede,
And take possession of the Diademe
Before this Harry, or his father king,
Who fetcht their title but from Lancaster,
Forth of that royall line. And being thus,
What reason ist but she should haue her right?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: I am resolu'de our enterprise is iust.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: Harry shall die, or else resigne his crowne.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Performe but that, and Charles the king of France
Shall ayde you lordes, not onely with his men,
But send you money to maintaine your warres,
Fiue hundred thousand crownes he bade me proffer,
If you can stop but Harries voyage for France.

sp.speaker: Scrope
sp.l: We neuer had a fitter time than now
The realme in such diuision as it is.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Besides, you must perswade ye there is due,
Vengeance for Richards murder, which although
It be defende, yet will it fall at last,
And now as likely as another time.
Sinne hath had many yeeres to ripen in,
And now the haruest cannot be farre off,
Wherein the weedes of vsurpation,
Are to be cropt, and cast into the fire.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: No more earle Cambridge, here I plight my faith,
To set vp thee, and thy renowned wife.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: Gray will performe the same, as he is knight.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: And to assist ye, as I said before,
Charters doth gage the honor of his king.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: We lacke but now Lord Cobhams fellowship,
And then our plot were absolute indeede.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Doubt not of him, my lord, his life's pursu'de
By th'incensed Cleargy, and of late,
Brought in displeasure with the king, assures
He may be quickly wonne vnto our faction.
Who hath the articles were drawne at large
Of our whole purpose?

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: That haue I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: We should not now be farre off from his house,
Our serious conference hath beguild the way,
See where his castle stands, giue me the writing.
When we are come vnto the speech of him,
Because we will not stand to make recount,
Of that which hath beene saide, here he shall reade enter Cob.
Our mindes at large, and what we craue of him.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: A ready way: here comes the man himselfe
Booted and spurrd, it seemes he hath beene riding.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Well met lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: My lord of Cambridge?
Your honor is most welcome into Kent,
And all the rest of this faire company.
I am new come from London, gentle Lordes:
But will ye not take Cowling for your host,
And see what entertainement it affordes?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: We were intended to haue beene your guests:
But now this lucky meeting shall suffise
To end our businesse, and deferre that kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Businesse my lord? what businesse should you haue
But to be mery? we haue no delicates,
But this Ile promise you, a peece of venison,
A cup of wine, and so forth: hunters fare:
And if you please, weele strike the stagge our selues
Shall fill our dishes with his wel-fed flesh.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: That is indeede the thing we all desire.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: My lordes, and you shall haue your choice with me.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Nay but the stagge which we desire to strike,
Liues not in Cowling: if you will consent,
And goe with vs, weele bring you to a forrest,
Where runnes a lusty hierd: amongst the which
There is a stagge superior to the rest,
A stately beast, that when his fellows runne,
He leades the race, and beates the sullen earth,
As though he scornd it with his trampling hoofes,
Aloft he beares his head, and with his breast,
Like a huge bulwarke counter-checkes the wind:
And when he standeth still, he stretcheth forth
His prowd ambitious necke, as if he meant
To wound the firmament with forked hornes.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Tis pitty such a goodly beast should die.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Not so, sir Iohn, for he is tyrannous,
And gores the other deere, and will not keep
Within the limites are appointed him.
Of late hees broke into a seueral,
Which doth belong to me, and there he spoiles
Both corne and pasture, two of his wilde race
Alike for stealth, and couetous incroatching,
Already are remou'd, if he were dead,
I should not onely be secure from hurt,
But with his body make a royall feast.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: How say you then, will you first hunt with vs?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Faith Lords, I like the pastime, wheres the place?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Peruse this writing, it will shew you all,
And what occasion we haue for the sport. he reades

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Call ye this hunting, my lords? Is this the stag
You faine would chase, Harry our dread king?
So we may make a banquet for the diuell,
And in the steede of wholsome meate, prepare
A dish of poison to confound our selues.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Why so lord Cobham? see you not our claime?
And how imperiously he holdes the crowne?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: besides, you know your selfe is in disgrace,
Held as a recreant, and pursude to death.
This will defend you from your enemies,
And stablish your religion through the land.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Notorious treason! yet I will conceale aside
My secret thoughts, to sound the depth of it.
My lord of Cambridge, I doe see your claime,
And what good may redound vnto the land,
By prosecuting of this enterprise.
But where are men? where's power and furniture
To order such an action? we are weake,
Harry, you know's a mighty potentate.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Tut, we are strong enough, you are belou'de,
And many will be glad to follow you,
We are the light, and some will follow vs:
Besides, there is hope from France: heres an embassador
That promiseth both men and money too.
The commons likewise (as we heare) pretend
A sodaine tumult, we wil ioyne with them.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Some likelihoode, I must confesse, to speede:
But how shall I beleeue this is plaine truth?
You are (my lords) such men as liue in Court,
And highly haue beene fauour'd of the king,
Especially lord Scroope, whome oftentimes
He maketh choice of for his bedfellow.
And you lord Gray are of his priuy councell:
Is not this a traine to intrappe my life?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Then perish may my soule: what thinke you so?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: Weele sweare to you.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: Or take the sacrament.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Nay you are noble men, and I imagine,
As you are honorable by birth and bloud,
So you will be in heart, in thought, in word.
I craue no other testimony but this.
That you would all subscribe, and set your hands
Vnto this writing which you gaue to me.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: With all our hearts: who hath any pen and inke?

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: My pocket should haue one: yea, heere it is.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Giue it me lord Scroope: there is my name.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.p: And there is my name.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Sir, let me craue,
That you would likewise write your name with theirs,
For confirmation of your maisters word,
The king of Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: That will I noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: So now this action is well knit together,
And I am for you: where's our meeting, lords?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Here if you please, the tenth of Iuly next.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: In Kent? agreed: now let vs in to supper,
I hope your honors will not away to night.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Yes presently, for I haue farre to ride,
About solliciting of other friends.

sp.speaker: Scroope
sp.l: And we would not be absent from the court,
Lest thereby grow suspition in the king.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Yet taste a cup of wine before ye go.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.p: Not now my lord, we thanke you: so farewell.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Farewell my noble lordes: my noble lords?
My noble villaines, base conspirators,
How can they looke his Highnesse in the face,
Whome they so closly study to betray?
But ile not sleepe vntill I make it knowne.
This head shall not be burdned with such thoughts,
Nor in this heart will I conceale a deede
Of such impietie against my king.
Madam, how now? Enter Harpoole and the rest.

sp.speaker: Lady cobh.
sp.l: You are welcome home, my Lord,
Why seeme ye so disquiet in your lookes?
What hath befalne you that disquiets your minde?

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.p: Bad newes I am afraide touching my husband.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Madam, not so: there is your husbands pardon,
Long may ye liue, each ioy vnto the other.

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.p: So great a kindnesse as I knowe not howe to make reply, my sense is quite confounded.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Let that alone: and madam stay me not,
For I must backe vnto the court againe
With all the speede I can: Harpoole, my horse.

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.p: So soone my Lord? what will you ride all night?

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: All night or day it must be so, sweete wife,
Vrge me not why or what my businesse is,
But get you in: Lord Powesse, beare with me,
And madam, thinke your welcome nere the worse:
My house is at your vse. Harpoole, away.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Shall I attend your lordship to the court?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Yea sir, your gelding, mount you presently exe.

sp.speaker: Lady Cobh.
sp.l: I prythee Harpoole, looke vnto thy Lord,
I do not like this sodaine posting backe.

sp.speaker: Powes
sp.l: Some earnest businesse is a foote belike,
What e're it be, pray God be his good guide.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.p: Amen that hath so highly vs bested.

sp.speaker: Lady Co.
sp.l: Come madam, and my lord, weele hope the best,
You shall not into Wales till he returne.

sp.speaker: Powesse
sp.p: Though great occasion be we should departe, yet madam will we stay to be resolude, of this vnlookt for doubtful accident. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Murley and his men, prepared in some filthy order for warre.

sp.speaker: Murly.
sp.p: Come my hearts of flint, modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomly, no man afore his Leader, follow your master, your Captaine, your Knight that shal be, for the honor of Meale-men, Millers, and Mault-men dunne is the mowse, Dicke and Tom for the credite of Dunstable, ding downe the enemie to morrow, ye shall not come into the field like beggars, where be Leonard and Laurence my two loaders, Lord haue mercie vpon vs, what a world is this? I would giue a couple of shillings for a dozen of good fethers for ye, and forty pence for as many skarffes to set ye out withall, frost and snow, a man has no heart to fight till he be braue.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Master I hope we be no babes, for our manhood, our bucklers, and our towne foote-balls can beare witnesse: and this lite parrell we haue shall off, and wee'l fight naked afore we runne away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Nay, I am of Laurence mind for that, for he meanes
to leaue his life behind him, he and Leonard your two loaders are making their wills because they haue wiues, now we Bachellers bid our friends scramble for our goods if we die: but master, pray ye let me ride vpon Cutte.

sp.speaker: Murly
sp.p: Meale and salt, wheat and mault, fire and tow, frost and snow, why Tom thou shalt: let me see, here are you, William and George are with my cart, and Robin and Hodge holding my owne two horses, proper men, handsom men, tall men, true men.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: But master, master, me thinkes you are a mad man, to hazard your owne person and a cart load of money too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yea, and maister theres a worse matter in't, if it be as I heard say, we go to fight against all the learned Bishops, that should giue vs their blessing, and if they curse vs, we shall speede nere the better.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Nay bir lady, some say the King takes their part, and master, dare you fight against the King?

sp.speaker: Murly
sp.p: Fie paltry, paltry in and out, to and fro vpon occasion, if the King be so vnwise to come there, weele fight with him too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What if we should kill the King?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Then weele make another.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Is that all, do ye not speake treason?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: If we do, who dare trippe vs? we come to fight for our conscience, and for honor, little know you what is in my bosome, looke here madde knaues, a paire of guilt spurres.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A paire of golden spurres? why do you not put them on your heeles? your bosome's no place for spurres.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Bee't more or lesse vpon occasion, Lord haue mercy vs, Tom th'art a foole, and thou speakest treason to knighthood, dare any weare golden or siluer spurs til he be a knight? no, I shall be knighted to morrow, and then they shall on: sirs, was it euer read in the church booke of Dunstable, that euer mault man was made knight?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No but you are more, you are meal-man, maultman, miller, corne-master and all.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Yea, and halfe a brewer too, and the diuell and all for wealth, you bring more money with you, than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: The more's my honor, I shal be a knight to morow, let me spose my men, Tom vpon cutte, Dicke vpon hobbe, Hodge vpon Ball, Raph vpon Sorell, and Robin vpon the forehorse.

div.stage: Enter Acton, Bourne, and Beuerley.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Stand, who comes there?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Al friends, good fellow.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: Friends and fellowes indeede sir Roger.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Why thus you shew your selfe a Gentleman,
To keepe your day, and come so well preparde,
Your cart stands yonder, guarded by your men,
Who tell me it is loaden well with come,
What summe is there?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Ten thousand pound sir Roger, and modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely, see what I haue here against I be knighted.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Gilt spurs? tis well.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: But where's our armie sir?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Disperst in sundry villages about,
Some here with vs in Hygate, some at Finchley,
Totnam, Enfield, Edmunton, Newington,
Islington, Hogsdon, Pancredge, Kenzington,
Some neerer Thames, Ratcliffe, Blackwall and Bow,
But our chiefe strength must be the Londoners,
Which ere the Sunne to morrow shine,
Will be nere fiftie thousand in the field.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Mary God dild ye daintie my deere, but vpon occasion sir Roger Acton, doth not the King know of it, and gather his power against vs.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: No, hee's secure at Eltham.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: What do the Cleargie?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Feare extreamly, yet prepare no force.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p:
In and out, to and fro, Bullie my boikin, we shall
shall the world afore vs, I vow by my worshippe, when I am knighted, weele take the King napping, if he stand on their part.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: This night we few in Higate will repose,
With the first cocke weele rise and arme our selues,
To be in Ficket fielde by breake of day,
And there expect our Generall.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Old-castle, what if he come not?

sp.speaker: Bourne
sp.l: Yet our action stands,
Sir Roger Acton may supply his place.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: True M. Bourne but who shall make me knight?

sp.speaker: Beuer.
sp.p: He that hath power to be our Generall.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Talke not of trifles, come lets away,
Our friends of London long till it be day. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Iohn of Wrootham and Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: By my troth, thou art as ielous a man as liues.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Canst thou blame me Doll, thou art my lands, my goods, my iewels, my wealth, my purse, none walks within xl. miles of London, but a plies thee as truely, as the parish does the poore mans boxe.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I am as true to thee, as the stone is in the wal, and thou knowest well enough sir Iohn, I was in as good doing, when I came to thee, as any wench neede to be: and therefore thou hast tried me, that thou hast: by Gods body, I wil not be kept as I haue bin, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Doll, if this blade holde, theres not a pedler walkes with a pack, but thou shalt as boldly chuse of his wares, as with thy ready mony in a Marchants shop, weele haue as good siluer as the King coynes any.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: What is al the gold spent you tooke the last day from the Courtier?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Tis gone Doll, tis flown, merely come, merely gon, he comes a horse backe that must pay for all, weele haue as good meate, as mony can get, and as good gownes, as can be bought for gold, be mery wench, the mault-man comes on munday.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: You might haue left me at Cobham, vntil you had bin better prouided for.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: No sweet Dol, no, I do not like that, yond old ruffian is not for the priest, I do not like a new cleark should come in the old bel-frie.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Ah thou art a mad priest yfaith.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Come Doll, Ile see thee safe at some alehouse here at Cray, and the next sheepe that comes shall leaue his fleece. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the King, Suffolke and Butler.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My lord of Suffolk, poste away for life,
And let our forces of such horse and foote,
As can be gathered vp by any meanes,
Make speedy randeuow in Tuttle fields,
It must be done this euening my Lord,
This night the rebells meane to draw to head
Neere Islington, which if your speede preuent not,
If once they should vnite their seuerall forces,
Their power is almost thought inuincible,
Away my Lord I will be with you soone.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.p: I go my Soueraigne with all happie speede. exit

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Make haste my lord of Suffolke as you loue vs,
Butler, poste you to London with all speede.
Commaund the Maior, and shrieues, on their alegiance,
The cittie gates be presently shut vp,
And guarded with a strong sufficient watch,
And not a man be suffered to passe,
Without a speciall warrant from our selfe.
Command the Posterne by the Tower be kept,
And proclamation on the paine of death,
That not a citizen stirre from his doores,
Except such as the Maior and Shrieues shall chuse,
For their owne guarde, and safety of their persons,
Butler away, haue care vnto my charge.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I goe my Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Goe downe by Greenewich, and command a boate,
At the Friers bridge attend my comming downe.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will my Lord. exit

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It's time I thinke to looke vnto rebellion,
When Acton doth expect vnto his ayd,
No lesse then fiftie thousand Londoners,
Well, Ile to Westminster in this disguise,
To heare what newes is stirring in these brawles.

div.stage: Enter sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.p: Stand true-man saies a thiefe?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Stand thiefe, saies a true man, how if a thiefe?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn
sp.p: Stand thiefe too.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then thiefe or true-man I see I must stand, I see how soeuer the world wagges, the trade of theeuing yet will neuer downe, what art thou?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: A good fellow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So am I too, I see thou dost know me.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: If thou be a good fellow, play the good fellowes part, deliuer thy purse without more adoe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I haue no mony.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I must make you find some before we part, if you haue no mony you shal haue ware, as many sound drie blows as your skin can carrie.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is that the plaine truth?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Sirra no more adoe, come, come, giue me the mony you haue, dispatch, I cannot stand all day.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Wel, if thou wilt needs haue it, there tis: iust the prouerb, one thiefe robs another, where the diuel are all my old theeues, that were wont to keepe this walke? Falstaffe the villaine is so fat, he cannot get on's horse, but me thinkes Poines and Peto should be stirring here abouts.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: How much is there on't of thy word?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A hundred pound in Angels, on my word,
The time has beene I would haue done as much
For thee, if thou hadst past this way, as I haue now.

sp.speaker: sir. Iohn
sp.p: Sirra, what art thou, thou seem'st a gentleman?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I am no lesse, yet a poore one now, for thou hast all my mony.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: From whence cam'st thou?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: From the court at Eltham.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Art thou one of the Kings seruants?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes that I am and one of his chamber.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I am glad thou art no worse, thou maist the better spare thy mony, & thinkst thou thou mightst get a poor thiefe his pardon if he should haue neede.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yes that I can.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wilt thou do so much for me, when I shall haue occasion?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes faith will I, so it be for no murther.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Nay, I am a pittifull thiefe, all the hurt I do a man, I take but his purse, Ile kill no man.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then of my word Ile do it.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Giue me thy hand of the same.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: There tis.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Me thinks the King should be good to theeues because he has bin a thiefe himselfe, though I thinke now he be turned true-man.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Faith I haue heard indeed he has had an il name that way in his youth, but how canst thou tell he has beene a thiefe?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: How? because he once robde me before I fell to the trade my selfe, when that foule villainous guts, that led him to all that rogery, was in's company there, that Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Well if he did rob thee then, thou art but euen with him now Ile be sworne: thou knowest not the king now, I thinke, if thou sawest him?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Not I yfaith.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So it should seeme.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Well, if old King Henry had liu'de, this King that is now, had made theeuing the best trade in England.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Because he was the chiefe warden of our company, it's pittie that ere he should haue bin a King, he was so braue a thiefe, but sirra, wilt remember my pardon if neede be?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes faith will I.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wilt thou? well then because thou shalt go safe, for thou mayest hap (being so earely) be met with againe, before thou come to Southwarke, if any man when he should bid thee good morrow, bid thee stand, say thou but sir Iohn, and he will let thee passe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is that the word? well then let me alone.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Nay sirra, because I thinke indeede I shall haue some occasion to vse thee, & as thou comst oft this way, I may light on thee another time not knowing thee, here, ile breake this Angell, take thou halfe of it, this is a token betwixt thee and me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: God haue mercy, farewell. exit

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: O my fine golden slaues, heres for thee wench yfaith, now Dol, we wil reuel in our beuer, this is a tyth pigge of my vicaridge, God haue mercy neigbour Shooters hill, you paid your tyth honestly. Wel I heare there is a company of rebelles vp against the King, got together in Ficket field neere Holborne, and as it is thought here in Kent, the King will be there to night in's owne person, well ile to the Kings camp, and it shall go hard, but if there be any doings, Ile make some good boote amongst them. exit.

div.stage: Enter King Henry, Suffolke, Huntington, and two with lights.

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: My Lords of Suffolke and of Huntington,
Who skouts it now? or who stands Sentinells?
What men of worth? what Lords do walke the round?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: May it please your Highnesse.

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: Peace, no more of that,
The King's asleepe, wake not his maiestie,
With termes nor titles, hee's at rest in bed,
Kings do not vse to watch themselues, they sleepe,
And let rebellion and conspiracie,
Reuel and hauocke in the common wealth,
Is London lookt vnto?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: It is my Lord,
Your noble Vncle Exceter is there,
Your brother Gloucester and my Lord of Warwicke,
Who with the maior and the Aldermen,
Do guard the gates, and keepe good rule within,
The Earle of Cambridge, and sir Thomas Gray,
Do walke the Round, Lord Scroope and Butler skout,
So though it please your maiestie to iest,
Were you in bed, well might you take your rest,

sp.speaker: K. Hen.
sp.l: I thank ye Lords, but you do know of old,
That I haue bin a perfect night-walker,
London you say is safely lookt vnto,
Alas poore rebels, there your ayd must faile,
And the Lord Cobham sir Iohn Old-castle,
Hee's quiet in Kent, Acton ye are deceiu'd,
Reckon againe, you count without your host,
To morrow you shall giue account to vs,
Til when my friends, this long cold winters night,
How can we spend? King Harry is a sleepe,
And al his Lords, these garments tel vs so,
Al friends at footebal, fellowes all in field,
Harry, and Dicke, and George, bring vs a drumme,
Giue vs square dice, weele keepe this court of guard,
For al good fellowes companies that come.
Wheres that mad priest ye told me was in Armes,
To fight, as wel as pray, if neede required?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Hees in the Camp, and if he knew of this,
I vndertake he would not be long hence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Trippe Dicke, Trippe George. they trippe.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: I must haue the dice,
What do we play at? the play at dice.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Passage if ye please.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Set round then, so, at all.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: George, you are out.
Giue me the dice, I passe for twentie pound,
Heres to our luckie passage into France.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Harry you passe indeede for you sweepe all.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: A signe king Harry shal sweep al in France. ent. sir Iohn

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Edge ye good fellowes, take a fresh gamster in.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Master Parson? we play nothing but gold?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: And fellow, I tel thee that the priest hath gold, gold? sbloud ye are but beggerly souldiers to me, I thinke I haue more gold than all you three.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: It may be so, but we beleeue it not.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Set priest set, I passe for all that gold.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Ye passe indeede.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Priest, hast thou any more?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Zounds what a question's that?
I tell thee I haue more then all you three,
At these ten Angells.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.l: I wonder how thou comst by all this gold,
How many benefices hast thou priest?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Yfaith but one, dost wonder how I come by gold? I wonder rather how poore souldiers should haue gold, for Ile tell thee good fellow, we haue euery day tythes, offerings, christnings, weddings, burialls: and you poore snakes come seldome to a bootie. Ile speake a prowd word, I haue but one parsonage, Wrootham, tis better than the Bishopprick of Rochester, theres nere a hill, heath, nor downe in all Kent, but tis in my parish, Barrham downe, Chobham downe, Gads hill, Wrootham hill, Blacke heath, Cockes heath, Birchen wood, all pay me tythe, gold quoth a? ye passe not for that.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Harry ye are out, now parson shake the dice.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
