sp.p: Set, set Ile couer ye at al: A plague on't I am out, the diuell, and dice, and a wench, who will trust them?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Saist thou so priest? set faire, at all for once.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Out sir, pay all.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Sbloud pay me angel gold,
Ile none of your crackt French crownes nor pistolets,
Pay me faire angel gold, as I pay you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No crackt french crownes? I hope to see more crackt french crownes ere long.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Thou meanest of French mens crownes, when the King is in France.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Set round, at all.

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.p: Pay all: this is some lucke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Giue me the dice, tis I must shread the priest:
At all sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: The diuell and all is yours: at that: sdeath, what wasting is this?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Well throwne Harry yfaith.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ile cast better yet.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Then Ile be hangd. Sirra, hast thou not giuen thy soule to the diuell for casting?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I passe for all.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Thou passest all that ere I playde withall:
Sirra, dost thou not cogge, nor foist, nor slurre?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Set parson, set, the dice die in my hand:
When parson, when? what can ye finde no more?
Alreadie drie? wast you bragd of your store?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Alls gone but that.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: What, halfe a broken angell?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Why sir, tis gold.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yea, and Ile couer it.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: The diuell do ye good on't, I am blinde, yee haue blowne me vp.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay tarry priest, ye shall not leaue vs yet,
Do not these peeces fit each other well?

sp.speaker: sir Ihon
sp.p: What if they do?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thereby beginnes a tale:
There was a thiefe, in face much like sir Iohn,
But t'was not hee, that thiefe was all in greene,
Met me last day on Blacke Heath, neere the parke,
With him a woman, I was al alone,
And weaponlesse, my boy had al my tooles,
And was before prouiding me a boate:
Short tale to make, sir Iohn, the thiefe I meane,
Tooke a iust hundreth pound in gold from me.
I storm'd at it, and swore to be reueng'de
If ere we met, he like a lusty,
Brake with his teeth this Angel iust in two,
To be a token at our meeting next,
Prouided, I should charge no Officer
To apprehend him, but at weapons point
Recouer that, and what he had beside.
Well met sir Iohn, betake ye to your tooles
By torch light, for master parson you are he
That had my gold.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Zounds I won't in play, in faire square play of the keeper of Eltham parke, and that I will maintaine with this poore whinyard, be you two honest men to stand and looke vpon's, and let's alone, and take neither part.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Agreede, I charge ye do not boudge a foot, Sir Iohn haue at ye.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Souldier ware your skonce.

div.stage: Here as they are ready to strike, enter Butler and drawes his weapon and steps betwixt them.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Hold villaines hold, my Lords, what do ye meane,
To see a traitor draw against the King?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: The King! Gods wil, I am in a proper pickle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Butler what newes? why dost thou trouble vs?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Please it your Highnesse, it is breake of day,
And as I skouted neere to Islington,
The gray ey'd morning gaue me glimmering,
Of armed men comming downe Hygate hill,
Who by their course are coasting hitherward.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let vs withdraw, my Lords, prepare our troopes,
To charge the rebels, if there be such cause,
For this lawd priest this diuellish hypocrite,
That is a thiefe, a gamster, and what not,
Let him be hang'd vp for example sake.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Not so my gracious soueraigne, I confesse I am a frayle man, flesh and bloud as other are: but set my imperfections aside, by this light ye haue not a taller man, nor a truer subiect to the Crowne and State, than Sir Iohn of Wrootham.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Wil a true subiect robbe his King?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Alas twas ignorance and want, my gracious liege.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Twas want of grace: why, you should be as salt
To season others with good document,
Your liues as lampes to giue the people light,
As shepheards, not as wolues to spoile the flock,
Go hang hm Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Didst thou not rob me?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I must confesse I saw some of your gold, but my dread Lord, I am in no humor for death, therfore saue my life, God will that sinners liue; do not you cause me die, once in their liues the best may goe astray, and if the world say true, your selfe (my liege) haue bin a thiefe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I confesse I haue,
But I repent and haue reclaimd my selfe.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: So will I do if you will giue me time.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Wilt thou? my lords, will you be his suerties?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: That when he robs againe, he shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I aske no more.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And we will grant thee that,
Liue and repent, and proue an honest man,
Which when I heare, and safe returne from France,
Ile giue thee liuing, till when take thy gold,
But spend it better then at cards or wine,
For better vertues fit that coate of thine.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Viuat Rex & currat lex, my liege, if ye haue cause of battell, ye shal see sir Iohn of Wrootham bestirre himselfe in your quarrel. exeunt.

div.stage: After an alarum enter Harry, Suffolk, Huntington, sir Iohn, bringing forth Acton, Beuerly, and Murley prisoners.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Bring in those traitors, whose aspiring minds,
Thought to haue triumpht in our ouerthrow,
But now ye see, base villaines, what successe
Attends ill actions wrongfully attempted.
Sir Roger Acton, thou retainst the name
Of knight, and shouldst be more discreetly temperd,
Than ioyne with peasants, gentry is diuine,
But thou hast made it more then popular.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Pardon my Lord, my conscience vrg'd me to it,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thy conscience? then thy conscience is corrupt,
For in thy conscience thou art bound to vs,
And in thy conscience thou shouldst loue thy country,
Else what's the difference twixt a Christian,
And the vnciuil manners of the Turke?

sp.speaker: Beuer.
sp.l: We meant no hurt vnto your maiesty,
But reformation of Religion.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Reforme Religion? was it that ye sought?
I pray who gaue you that authority?
Belike then we do hold the scepter vp,
And sit within the throne but for a cipher,
Time was, good subiects would make knowne their griefe,
And pray amendment, not inforce the same,
Vnlesse their King were tyrant, which I hope
You cannot iustly say that Harry is,
What is that other?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: A mault-man my Lord,
And dwelling in Dunstable as he saies.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sirra what made you leaue your barly broth,
To come in armour thus against your King?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: Fie paltry, paltry to and fro, in and out vpon occasion, what a worlde's this? knight-hood (my liege) twas knighthood brought me hither, they told me I had wealth enough to make my wife a lady.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And so you brought those horses which we saw,
Trapt all in costly furniture, and meant
To weare these spurs when you were knighted once.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.p: In and out vpon occasion I did.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: In and out vppon occasion, therefore you shall be hang'd, and in the sted of wearing these spurres vpon your heeles, about your necke they shall bewray your folly to the world.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: In and out vpon ocasion, that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Mur
sp.p: Fic paltry paltry, to and fro, good my liege a pardon, I am sory for my fault.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That comes too late: but tell me, went there none
Beside sir Roger Acton, vpon whom
You did depend to be your gouernour?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None none my Lord, but sir Iohn Old-castle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Beares he part in this conspiracie. enter Bishop

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: We lookt my Lord that he would meet vs here.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But did he promise you that he would come.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.p: Such letters we receiued forth of Kent.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Where is my Lord the King? health to your grace,
Examining my Lord some of these caitiue rebels,
It is a generall voyce amongst them all,
That they had neuer come vnto this place,
But to haue met their valiant general,
The good Lord Cobham as they title him,
Whereby, my Lord, your grace may now perceiue,
His treason is apparant, which before
He sought to colour by his flattery.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Now by my roialtie I would haue sworne,
But for his conscience, which I beare withall,
There had not liude a more true hearted subiect.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: It is but counterfeit, my gracious lords,
And therefore may it please your maiestie,
To set your hand vnto this precept here,
By which weel cause him forthwith to appeare,
And answer this by order of the law.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Bishop, not only that, but take commission,
To search, attach, imprison, and condemne,
This most notorious traitor as you please.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: It shall be done, my Lord, without delay:
So now I hold Lord Cobham in my hand,
That which shall finish thy disdained life.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I thinke the yron age begins but now,
(Which learned poets haue so often taught)
Wherein there is no credit to be giuen,
To either wordes, or lookes, or solemne oathes,
For if there were, how often hath he sworne,
How gently tun'de the musicke of his tongue,
And with what amiable face beheld he me,
When all, God knowes, was but hypocrisie. enter Cobham.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Long life and prosperous raigne vnto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ah villaine, canst thou wish prosperitie,
Whose heart includeth naught but treacherie?
I do arrest thee here my selfe, false knight,
Of treason capitall against the state.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Of treason mightie prince, your grace mistakes,
I hope it is but in the way of mirth.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thy necke shall feele it is in earnest shortly,
Darst thou intrude into our presence, knowing
How haynously thou hast offended vs?
But this is thy accustomed deceit,
Now thou perceiust thy purpose is in vaine,
With some excuse or other thou wilt come,
To cleere thy selfe of this rebellion.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Rebellion good my Lord, I know of none.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: If you deny it, here is euidence,
See you these men, you neuer councelled,
Nor offerd them assistance in their warres

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Speake sirs, not one but all, I craue no fauour,
Haue euer I beene conuersant with you,
Or written letters to incourage you,
Or kindled but the least or smallest part,
Of this your late vnnaturall rebellion?
Speake for I dare the vttermost you can.

sp.speaker: Mur,
sp.p: In and out vpon occasion I know you not.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, didst not say that sir Iohn Old-castle,
Was one with whom you purposde to haue met?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: True, I did say so, but in what respect?
Because I heard it was reported so.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Was there no other argument but that?

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: To cleere my conscience ere I die my lord,
I must confesse, we haue no other ground
But only Rumor, to accuse this lord,
Which now I see was merely fabulous.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The more pernitious you to taint him then,
Whome you knew not was faulty yea or no.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: Let this my Lord, which I present your grace
Speake for my loyalty, reade these articles,
And then giue sentence of my life or death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Earle Cambridge, Scroope, and Gray corrupted
With bribes from Charles of France, either to winne
My Crowne from me, or secretly contriue
My death by treason? Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.l: There is the platforme, and their hands, my lord,
Each seuerally subscribed to the same.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Oh neuer heard of base ingratitude!
Euen those I hugge within my bosome most,
Are readiest euermore to sting my heart.
Pardon me Cobham, I haue done thee wrong,
Heereafter I will liue to make amends.
Is then their time of meeting so neere hand?
Weele meete with them, but little for their ease,
If God permit: goe take these rebells hence,
Let them haue martiall law: but as for thee,
Friend to thy king and country, still be free. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.l: Be it more or lesse, what a world is this?
Would I had continued still of the order of knaues,
And neuer sought knighthood, since it costes
So deere: sir Roger, I may thanke you for all.

sp.speaker: Acton
sp.l: Now tis too late to haue it remedied,
I prithee Murley doe not vrge me with it.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: Will you away, and make no more to do?

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.l: Fy paltry paltry, to and fro, as occasion serues,
If you be so hasty take my place.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: No good sir knight, you shall begin in your hand.

sp.speaker: Murl.
sp.p: I could be glad to giue my betters place. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bishop, lord Warden, Croamer the Shrieue, Lady Cob and attendants.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I tell ye Lady, its not possible
But you should know where he conueies himselfe,
And you haue hid him in some secret place.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My Lord, beleeue me, as I haue a soule,
I know not where my lord my husband is.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Go to, go to ye are an heretike,
And will be forc'de by torture to confesse,
If faire meanes will not serue to make ye tell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My husband is a noble gentleman,
And neede not hide himselfe for anie fact
That ere I heard of, therefore wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Your husband is a dangerous schismaticke,
Traitor to God, the King, and common wealth,
And therefore master Croamer shrieue of Kent,
I charge you take her to your custodie,
And ceaze the goods of Sir John Old-castle
To the Kings vse, let her go in no more,
To fetch so much as her apparell out,
There is your warrant from his maiestie.

sp.speaker: L. War.
sp.l: Good my Lord Bishop pacifie your wrath
Against the Lady.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Then let her confesse
Where Old-castle her husband is conceald.

sp.speaker: L. War.
sp.l: I dare engage mine honor and my life,
Poore gentlewoman, she is ignorant,
And innocent of all his practises,
If any euill by him be practised.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: If my Lord Warden? nay then I charge you,
That all the cinque Ports whereof you are chiefe
Be laid forthwith, that he escape vs not,
Shew him his highnesse warrant M. Shrieue.

sp.speaker: L. War.
sp.p: I am sorie for the noble gentleman, Enter Old-castle & Harp.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Peace, he comes here, now do your office.

sp.speaker: Old-castle
sp.l: Harpoole what businesse haue we here in hand?
What makes the Bishop and the Sheriffe here,
I feare my comming home is dangerous,
I would I had not made such haste to Cobham.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Be of good cheere my Lord, if they be foes weele scramble shrewdly with them, if they be friends they are welcome: one of them (my Lord, Warden) is your friend, but me thinkes my ladie weepes, I like not that.

sp.speaker: Croo.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Old-castle Lord Cobham, in the Kings maiesties name, I arrest ye of high treason.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.p: Treason M. Croomes?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Treason M. Shrieue, sbloud what treason?

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Harpoole I charge thee stirre not, but be quiet still,
Do ye arrest me M. Shrieue for treason?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Yea of high treason, traitor, heretike.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Defiance in his face that calls me so,
I am as true a loyall gentleman
Vnto his highnesse, as my prowdest enemie,
The King shall witnesse my late faithfull seruice,
For safety of his sacred maiestie.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: What thou art, the kings hand shall testifie,
Shewt him Lord Warden.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Iesu defend me,
Is't possible your cunning could so temper
The princely disposition of his mind,
To signe the damage of a royall subiect?
Well, the best is, it beares an ancedate,
Procured by my absence, and your malice,
But I, since that, haue shewd my selfe as true,
As any churchman that dare challenge me,
Let me be brought before his maiestie,
If he acquite me not, then do your worst.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: We are not bound to do kind offices
For any traitor, schismatike, nor heretike,
The kings hand is our warrant for our worke,
Who is departed on his way for France,
And at Southhampton doth repose this night.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: O that it were the blessed will of God, that thou and I were within twenty mile of it, on Salisbury plaine! I would lose my head if euer thou broughtst thy head hither againe. aside.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.p: My Lord Warden o'th cinque Ports, & my Lord of Rochester, ye are ioynt Commissioners, fauor me so much, On my expence to bring me to the king.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: What, to Southhampton?

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Thither my god Lord,
And if he do not cleere me of al guilt,
And all suspition of conspiracie,
Pawning his princely warrant for my truth:
I aske no fauour, but extreamest torture.
Bring me, or send me to him, good my Lord,
Good my Lord Warden, M Shrieue, entreate.
sp.stage: Here the Lord Warden, and Cromer vncouer to the Bishop, and secretly whispers with him.
sp.l: Come hither lady, nay, sweet wife forbeare,
To heape one sorrow on anothers necke,
Tis griefe enough falsly to be accusde,
And not permitted to acquite my selfe,
Do not thou with thy kind respectiue teares,
Torment thy husbands heart that bleedes for thee,
But be of comfort, God hath help in store,
For those that put assured trust in him.
Deere wife, if they commit me to the Tower,
Come vp to London to your sisters house:
That being neere me, you may comfort me.
One solace find I setled in my soule,
That I am free from treasons very thought,
Only my conscience for the Gospels sake,
Is cause of all the troubles I sustaine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my deere Lord, what shall betide of vs?
You to the Tower, and I turnd out of doores,
Our substance ceaz'd vnto his highnesse vse,
Euen to the garments longing to our backes.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Patience good madame, things at worst will mend,
And if they doe not, yet our liues may end.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Vrge it no more, for if an Angell spake,
I sweare by sweet saint Peters blessed keyes,
First goes he to the Tower, then to the stake.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: But by your leaue, this warrant doth not stretch
To imprison her.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: No, turne her out of doores, L. Warden and Oldcastle whisper.
Euen as she is, and leade him to the Tower,
With guard enough for feare of rescuing.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O God requite thee thou bloud-thirsty man.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: May it not be my Lord of Rochester?
Wherein haue I incurd your hate so farre,
That my appeale vnto the King's denide?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: No hate of mine, but power of holy church,
Forbids all fauor to false heretikes.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Your priuate malice more than publike power,
Strikes most at me, but with my life it ends.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: O that I had the Bishop in that feare, aside
That once I had his Sumner by our selues.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: My Lord yet graunt one sute vnto vs all,
That this same auncient seruing man may waite
Vpon my lord his master in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: This old iniquitie, this heretike?
That in contempt of our church discipline,
Compeld my Sumner to deuoure his processet
Old Ruffian past-grace, vp start schismatike,
Had not the King prayd vs to pardon ye,
Ye had fryed for it, ye grizild heretike.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
Sbloud my lord Bishop, ye do me wrong, I am neither
heretike nor puritane, but of the old church, ile sweare, drinke ale, kisse a wench, go to masse, eate fish all Lent, and fast fridaies with cakes and wine, fruite and spicerie, shriue me of my old sinnes afore Easter, and beginne new afore whitsontide.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: A merie mad conceited knaue my lord.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: That knaue was simply put vpon the Bishop.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Wel, God forgiue him and I pardon him.
Let him attend his master in the Tower,
For I in charity wish his soule no hurt.

sp.speaker: Oldca
sp.p: God blesse my soule from such cold charitie,

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Tooth Tower with him, and when my leisure serues,
I will examine him of Articles,
Looke my lord Warden as you haue in charge,
The Shriue performe his office.

sp.speaker: L. Ward.
sp.p: Yes my lord. Enter the Sumner with bookes.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: What bringst thou there? what? bookes of heresie.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Yea my lord, heres not a latine booke,
No not so much as our ladies Psalter,
Heres the Bible, the testament the Psalmes in meter,
The sickemans salue, the treasure of gladnesse,
And al in English, not so much but the Almanack's English.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Away with them, to'th fire with them Clun,
Now fie vpon these vpstart heretikes,
Al English, burne them, burne them quickly Clun.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: But doe not Sumner as voule answere it, for I haue there English bookes my lord, that ile not part with for your Bishoppricke, Beuis of Hampton, Owleglasse, the Frier and the Boy, Ellen of Rumming, Robin hood, and other such godly stories which if ye burne, by this flesh ile make ye drink their ashes in S. Margets ale. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Bishop of Rochester with his men, in liuerie coates.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Is it your honors pleasure we shal stay,
Or come backe in the afternoone to fetch you.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Now you haue brought me heere into the Tower,
You may go backe vnto the Porters Lodge,
And send for drinke or such things as you want,
Where if I haue occasion to imploy you,
Ile send some officer to cal you to me.
Into the cittie go not, I commaund you,
Perhaps I may haue present neede to vse you.

sp.p: We will attend your worship here without.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Do so I pray you.
Come, we may haue a quart of wine at the Rose at Barking, I warrant you, and come backe an hower before he be ready to go.
We must hie vs then.
Let's away. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Ho, M. Lieftenant.

sp.speaker: Lieften.
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: A friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Lieften.
sp.p: My lord of Rochester, your honor's welcome.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Sir heres my warrant from the Counsell,
For conference with sir Iohn Old-castle,
Vpon some matter of great consequence.

sp.speaker: Lieften.
sp.p: Ho, sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Lieften.
sp.p: Harpoole, tel Sir Iohn, that my lord of Rochester comes from the counsell to conferre with him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: I thinke you may as safe without suspition,
As any man in England as I heare,
For it was you most labor'd his commitment.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: I did sir, and nothing repent it I assure you.
M. Lieftenant I pray you giue vs leaue,
I must conferre here with sir Iohn a little.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: With all my heart my lord.

sp.speaker: Harp aside.
sp.p: My lord be rulde by me, take this occasion while tis offered, and on my life your lordship shal escape.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: No more I say, peace lest he should suspect it.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Sir Iohn I am come vnto you from the lords of his highnesse most honorable counsell, to know if yet you do recant your errors, conforming you vnto the holy church.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: My lord of Rochester on good aduise,
I see my error, but yet vnderstand me,
I meane not error in the faith I hold,
But error in submitting to your pleasure,
Therefore your lordship without more to do.
Must be a meanes to help me to escape.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: What meanes? thou heretike?
Darst thou but lift thy hand against my calling?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: No not to hurt yon for a thousand pound,

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nothing but to borrow your vpper garments a little; not a word more, for if you do, you die: peace, for waking the children, there, put them on, dispatch, my lord, the window that goes out into the leads, is sure enough, I told you that before, there, make you ready, ile conuay him after, and bind him surely in the inner roome.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: This is wel begun, God send vs happie speed,
Hard shift you see men make in time of need: Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Heere my Lord, come come away.

div.stage: Enter seruing men againe.

sp.p: I maruell that my lord should stay so long.
He hath sent to seeke vs, I dare lay my life.
We come in good time, see where he is comming.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I beseech you good my lord of Rochester, be fauorable to my lord and maister.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.l: The inner roomes be very hot and close,
I do not like this ayre here in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.p: His case is hard my lord, you shall safely get out of the Tower, but I will downe vpon them, in which time get you away.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Fellow thou troublest me.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p:
Heare me my Lord, hard vnder Islington wait you my comming, I will bring my Lady ready, with horses
to conuay you hence.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Fellow, go back againe vnto thy Lord and counsell him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nay my good lord of Rochester, ile bring you to S. Albons through the woods, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old-ca.
sp.p: Villaine away.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Nay since I am past the Towers libertie, thou part'st not so. be drawes.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: Clubbes clubs, clubs.
Murther, murther murther.
Downe with him. they fight.
A villaine traitor.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: You cowardly rogues. sir Iohn escapes.

div.stage: Enter Lieftenant and his men.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.l: Who is so bold as dare to draw a sword,
So neare vnto the entrance of the Tower?

sp.p: This ruffian seruant to sir Iohn Old-castle was like to haue slaine my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lieft.
sp.p: Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Stand off if you loue your puddings.

div.stage: Rochester calls within.

sp.speaker: Rock
sp.p: Help help, help, M. Lieftenant help.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Who's that within? some treason in the Tower vpon my life, looke in, who's that which calls? enter Roch. bound.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Without your cloke my lord of Rochester?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: There, now it workes, then let me speed, for now is the fittest time for me to scape away. exit

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Why do you looke so ghastly and affrighted?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: Old-castle that traitor and his man,
When you had left me to conferre with him,
Tooke, bound, and stript me, as you see,
And left me lying in his inner chamber,
And so departed, and I

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: And you! ne're say that the Lord Cobhams man
Did here set vpon you like to murther you.

sp.p: And so he did.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.l: It was vpon his master then he did,
That in the brawle the traitor might escape.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.p: Where is this Harpoole?
Here he was euen now.

sp.speaker: Lief.
sp.l: Where can you tell? they are both escap'd,
Since it so happens that he is escap'de,
I am glad you are a witnesse of the same,
It might haue else beene laid vnto my charge,
That I had beene consenting to the fact.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Come, search shal be made for him with expedition, the hauens laid that he shall not escape, and hue and crie continue thorough England, to find this damned dangerous heretike. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Cambridge, Scroope, and Gray, as in a chamber, and set downe at a table, consulting about their treason: King Harry and Suffolke listning at the doore.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: In mine opinion, Scroope hath well aduisde,
Poison will be the only aptest meane,
And fittest for our purpose to dispatch him.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.l: But yet there may be doubt in their deliuery,
Harry is wise, therefore Earle of Cambridge,
I Iudge that way not so conuenient.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.l: What thinke ye then of this? I am his bedfellow,
And vnsuspected nightly sleepe with him.
What if I venture in those silent houres,
When sleepe hath sealed vp all mortall eies,
To murder him in bed? how like ye that?

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Herein consistes no safetie for your selfe,
And you disclosde, what shall become of vs?
But this day (as ye know) he will aboord,
The wind so faire, and set away for France,
If as he goes, or entring in the ship,
It might be done, then it were excellent,

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.l: Why any of these, or if you will,
Ile cause a present sitting of the Councell,
Wherein I will pretend some matter of such weight,
As needes must haue his royall company,
And to dispatch him in the Councell chamber.

sp.speaker: Camb.
sp.l: Tush, yet I heare not any thing to purpose,
I wonder that lord Cobham staies so long,
His counsell in this case would much auaile vs.

div.stage: They rise from the table, and the King steps in to them with his Lordes.

sp.speaker: Scroop
sp.p: What shal we rise thus, and determine nothing?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That were a shame indeede, no, sit againe,
And you shall haue my counsell in this case,
If you can find no way to kill this King,
Then you shall see how I can further ye,
Scroopes way by poison was indifferent,
But yet being bed-fellow vnto the King,
And vnsuspected sleeping in his bosome,
In mine opinion, that's the likelier way,
For such false friends are able to do much,
And silent night is Treason's fittest friend,
Now, Cambridge in his setting hence for France,
Or by the way, or as he goes aboord,
To do the deed, that was indifferent too,
Yet somewhat doubtful; might I speake my mind,
For many reasons needelesse now to vrge.
Mary Lord Gray came something neare the point,
To haue the King at councell, and there murder him,
As Caesar was amongst his dearest friends:
None like to that, if all were of his mind.
Tell me oh tel me you bright honors staines,
For which of all my kindnesses to you,
Are ye become thus traitors to your king?
And France must haue the spoile of Harries life?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh pardon vs dread lord. all kneeling.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How pardon ye? that were a sinne indeed,
Drag them to death, which iustly they deserue, they leade them away.
And France shall dearely buy this villany,
So soone as we set footing on her breast,
God haue the praise for our deliuerance,
And next, our thankes (Lord Cobham) is to thee,
True perfect mirror of nobilitie. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the hoste, sir Iohn Old-castle, and Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome to this house, to such as heere is with all my heart, but by the masse I feare your lodging wilbe the woorst, l haue but two beds, and they are both in a chamber, and the carier and his daughter lies in the one, and you and your wife must lie in the other.

sp.speaker: L. Cobh.
sp.l: In faith sir, for my selfe I doe not greatly passe,
My wife is weary, and would be at rest,
For we haue traueld very far to day,
We must be content with such as you haue.

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: But I cannot tell how to doe with your man.

sp.speaker: Harpoole
sp.p: What, hast thou neuer an empty roome in thy house for me?

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: Not a bedde by my troth: there came a poore Irish man, and I lodgde him in the barne, where he has faire straw, though he haue nothing else.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Well mine hoste, I pray thee helpe mee to a payre of faire sheetes, and Ile go lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: By the masse that thou shalt, a good payre of hempen sheetes, were neuer laine in: Come. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Constable, Maior, and Watch.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: What haue you searcht the towne?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: All the towne sir, we haue not left a house vnsearcht that vses to lodge.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: Surely my lord of Rochester was then deceiude,
Or ill informde of sir Iohn Old-castle,
Or if he came this way, hees past the towne,
He could not else haue scapt you in the search.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: The priuy watch hath beene abroad all night,
And not a stranger lodgeth in the towne
But he is knowne, onely a lusty priest
We found in bed with a pretty wench,
That sayes she is his wife, yonder at the sheeres:
But we haue chargde the hoste with his forth comming
To morow morning.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: What thinke you best to do?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith maister maior, heeres a few stragling houses beyond the bridge, and a little Inne where cariers vse to lodge, though I thinke surely he would nere lodge there: but weele go search, & the rather, because there came notice to the towne the last night of an Irish man, that had done a murder, whome we are to make search for.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Come I pray you, and be circumspect. exeunt

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: First beset the house, before you begin the search.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Content, euery man take a seuerall place.
sp.stage: heere is heard a great noyse within.
sp.l: Keepe, keepe, strike him downe there, downe with him.

div.stage: Enter Constable with the Irish man in Harpooles apparell.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Come you villainous heretique, confesse where your maister is.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Vat mester?

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Vat mester, you counterfeit rebell, this shall not serue your turne.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Be sent Patrike I ha no mester.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Wheres the lord Cobham sir Iohn Old-castle that lately is escaped out of the Tower.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Vat lort Cobham?

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: You counterfeit, this shal not serue you, weele torture you, weele make you to confesse where that arch-heretique Lord Cobham is: come binde him fast.

sp.speaker: Irish man
sp.p: Ahone, ahone, ahone, a Cree.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ahone, you crafty rascall? exeunt.

div.stage: Lord Cobham comes out in his gowne stealing.

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Harpoole, Harpoole, I heare a maruelous noyse about the house, God warant vs, I feare wee are pursued: what Harpoole.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Who calles there?

sp.speaker: Cobh.
sp.p: Tis I, dost thou not heare a noyse about the house?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Yes mary doe I, zwounds, I can not finde my hose, this Irish rascall that was lodgde with me all night, hath stolne my apparell, and has left me nothing but a lowsie mantle, and a paire of broags. Get vp, get vp, and if the carier and his wench be asleep, change you with them as he hath done with me, and see if we can escape.

div.stage: A noyse againe heard about the house, a pretty while, then enter the Constable meeting Harpoole in the Irish mans apparrell.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Stand close, heere comes the Irish man that didde the murther, by all tokens, this is he.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: And perceiuing the house beset, would get away: stand sirra.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: What art thou that bidst me stand?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am the Officer, and am come to search for an Irish man, such a villaine as thy selfe, that hast murthered a man this last night by the hie way.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: Sbloud Constable, art thou madde? am I an Irish man?

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Sirra, weele finde you an Irish man before we part: lay hold vpon him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Make him fast: O thou bloudy rogue!

div.stage: Enter Lord Cobham and his lady in the carrier and wenches apparrell.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What will these Ostlers sleepe all day?
Good morow, good morow, Come wench, come,
Saddle, saddle, now afore God too foord-dayes, ha?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Who comes there?

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Oh tis Lankashire carier, let him passe.

sp.speaker: Cobham
sp.l: What, will no body open the gates here?
Come, lets int stable to looke to our capons.

div.stage: The carrier calling.

sp.speaker: Club calling
sp.p: Hoste, why ostler, zwookes, heres such abomination company of boies: a pox of this pigstie at the house end, it filles all the house full of fleas, ostler, ostler.

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: Who calles there, what would you haue?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Zwookes, do you robbe your ghests? doe you lodge rogues and slaues, and scoundrels, ha? they ha stolne our doths here: why ostler?

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: A murrein choake you, what a bawling you keepe.

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: How now, what woulde the carrier haue? looke vp there.

sp.speaker: Ostler
sp.p: They say that the man and woman that lay by them haue stolne their clothes.

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: What, are the strange folkes vp yet that came in yester night?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What mine hoste, vp so early?

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: What, maister Maior, and maister Constable!

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: We are come to seeke for some suspected persons, and such as heere we found, haue apprehended.

div.stage: Enter the Carrier and Kate in lord Cobham and ladies apparell.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Who comes heere?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Who comes here? a plague found ome, you bawle quoth a, ods hat, Ile forzweare your house, you lodgde a fellow and his wife by vs that ha runne away with our parrel, and left vs such gew-gawes here, come Kate, come to mee, thowse dizeard yfaith.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Mine hoste, know you this man?

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: Yes maister Maior, Ile giue my word for him, why neibor Club, how comes this geare about?

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Now a fowle ont, I can not make this gew-gaw stand on my head, now the lads and the lasses won flowt me too too

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How came this man and woman thus attired?

sp.speaker: Hoste
sp.p: Here came a man and woman hither this last night, which I did take for substantiall people, and lodgde all in one chamber by these folkes: mee thinkes, haue beene so bolde to change apparell, and gone away this morning ere they rose.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: That was that villaine traitour Old-castle, that thus escaped vs: make out huy and cry yet after him, keepe fast that traiterous rebell his seruant there: farewell mine hoste.

sp.speaker: Carier
sp.p: Come Kate Owdham, thou and Ise trimly dizard.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p:
I faith neame Club, Ise wot nere what to do, Ise be so
flowted and so showted at: but by th messe Ise cry. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Priest and Doll.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Come Dol, come, be mery wench,
Farewell Kent, we are not for thee,
Be lusty my lasse, come for Lancashire,
We must nip the Boung for these crownes.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Why is all the gold spent already that you had the other day?

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Gone Doll, gone, flowne, spent, vanished, the diuel, drinke and the dice, has deuoured all.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: You might haue left me in Kent, that you might, vntil you had bin better prouided, I could haue staied at Cobham.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: No Dol, no, ile none of that, Kent's too hot Doll, Kent's too hot: the weathercocke of Wrotham will crow no longer, we haue pluckt him, he has lost his feathers, I haue prunde him bare, left him thrice, is moulted, is moulted, wench.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Faith sir Iohn, I might haue gone to seruice againe, old maister Harpoole told me he would prouide me a mistris.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Peace Doll, peace, come mad wench, Ile make thee an honest woman, weele into Lancashire to our friends, the troth is, Ile marry thee, we want but a little mony to buy vs a horse, and to spend by the way, the next sheep that comes shal loose his fleece, weele haue these crownes wench I warrant thee: stay, who comes here? some Irish villaine me thinkes that enter the Irish man with his master slaine .has slaine a man, and drawes him out of the way to rifle him: stand close Doll, weele see the end. The Irish man falls to rifle his master .Alas poe mester, S. Rishard Lee, be saint Patricke is rob and cut thy trote, for dee shame, and dy money, and dee gold ring, be me truly is loue thee wel, but now dow be kil thee, bee shitten kanaue.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn.
sp.p: Stand sirra, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Irishman.
sp.p: Be saint Patricke mester is pore Irisman, is a leufter.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
Sirra, sirra, you are a damned rogue, you haue killed a man here, and rifled him of all that he has, sbloud you
rogue deliuer, or ile not leaue you so much as an Irish haire aboue your shoulders, you whorson Irish dogge, sirra vntrusse presently, come off and dispatch, or by this crosse ile fetch your head off as cleane as a barke.

sp.speaker: Irishman.
sp.p: Wees me saint Patricke, Ise kill me mester for chaine and his ring, and nows be rob of all, mees vndoo.

div.stage: Priest robs him.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Auant you rascal, go sirra, be walking, come Doll the diuel laughes, when one theefe robs another, come madde wench, weele to saint Albons, and reuel in our bower, hey my braue girle.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: O thou art old sir Iohn, when all's done yfaith.

div.stage: Enter the hoste of the Bell with the Irish man.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.p: Be me tro mester is pore Irisman, is want iudging, is haue no mony, is starue and cold, good mester giue her some meate, is famise and tie.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Yfaith my fellow I haue no lodging, but what I keep for my guesse, that I may not disapoint, as for meate thou shalt haue such as there is, & if thou wilt lie in the barne, theres faire straw, and roome enough.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.p: Is thanke my mester hartily, de straw is good bed for me.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Ho Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Shew this poore Irishman into the barne, go sirra. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter carrier and Kate.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Ho, who's within here, who lookes to the horses? Gods hatte heres fine worke, the hens in the manger, and the hogs in the litter, a bots found you all, heres a house well lookt too yvaith.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.p: Mas goffe Club, Ise very cawd.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Get in Kate, get in to fier and warme thee.

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Ho Iohn Hostler.

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.l: What gaffer Club, welcome to saint Albons,
How does all our friends in Lancashire?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Well God haue mercie Iohn, how does Tom, wheres he?

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.p: O Tom is gone from hence, hees at the three horse-loues at Stony-stratford, how does old Dick Dunne?

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Gods hatte old Dunne has bin moyerd in a slough in Brickhil-lane, a plague found it, yonder is such abhomination weather as neuer was seene.

sp.speaker: Hostler.
sp.p: Gods hat thiefe, haue one half pecke of pease and oates more for that, as I am Iohn Ostler, hee has been euer as good a iade as euer traueld.

sp.speaker: Club
sp.p: Faith well said old Iacke, thou art the old lad stil.

sp.speaker: Hostler
sp.p: Come Gaffer Club, vnlode, vnlode, and get to supper, and Ile rub dunne the while. Come. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Iohn Old-castle, and his Lady disguisde.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Come Madam, happily escapt, here let vs sit,
This place is farre remote from any path,
And here awhile our weary limbs may rest,
To take refreshing, free from the pursuite
Of enuious Winchester.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But where (my Lord,)
Shall we find rest for our disquiet minds?
There dwell vntamed thoughts that hardly stoupe,
To such abasement of disdained rags,
We were not wont to trauell thus by night,
Especially on foote.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: No matter loue,
Extremities admit no better choice,
And were it not for thee, say froward time,
Imposde a greater taske, I would esteeme it
As lightly as the wind that blowes vpon vs,
But in thy sufferance I am doubly taskt,
Thou wast not wont to haue the earth thy stoole,
Nor the moist dewy grasse thy pillow, nor
Thy chamber to be the wide horrison,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How can it seeme a trouble, hauing you
A partner with me, in the worst I feele?
No gentle Lord, your presence would giue ease
To death it selfe, should he now seaze vpon me,
Behold what my foresight hath vndertane heres bread and cheese & a bottle.
For feare we faint, they are but homely cates.
Yet saucde with hunger, they may seeme as sweete,
As greater dainties we were wont to taste.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Praise be to him whose plentie sends both this,
And all things else our mortall bodies need,
Nor scorne we this poore feeding, nor the state
We now are in, for what is it on earth,
Nay vnder heauen, continues at a stay?
Ebbes not the sea, when it hath ouerflowne?
Flowes not darknes when the day is gone?
And see we not sometime the eie of heauen,
Dimmd with ouerflying clowdes: there's not that worke
Of carefull nature, or of cunning art,
(How strong, how beauteous, or how rich it be)
But falls in time to ruine: here gentle Madame,
In this one draught I wash my sorrow downe. drinkes.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And I incoragde with your cheerefull speech,
Wil do the like.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Pray God poore Harpoole come,
If he should fall into the Bishops hands,
Or not remember where we bade him meete vs,
It were the thing of all things else, that now
Could breede reuolt in this new peace of mind.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, hees witty to deuise,
And strong to execute a present shift.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: That power be stil his guide hath guided vs,
My drowsie eies waxe heauy, earely rising,
Together with the trauell we haue had,
Make me that I could gladly take a nap,
Were I perswaded we might be secure.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Let that depend on me, whilst you do sleepe,
Ile watch that no misfortune happen vs,
Lay then your head vpon my lap sweete Lord,
And boldly take your rest.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: I shal deare wife,
Be too much trouble to thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Vrge not that,
My duty binds me, and your loue commands.
I would I had the skil with tuned voyce,
To draw on sleep with some sweet melodie,
But imperfection and vnaptnesse too,
Are both repugnant, feare inserts the one,
The other nature hath denied me vse.
But what talke I of meanes to purchase that,
Is freely hapned? sleepe with gentle hand,
Hath shut his eie-liddes, oh victorious labour,
How soone thy power can charme the bodies sense?
And now thou likewise climbst vnto my braine,
Making my heauy temples stoupe to thee,
Great God of heauen from danger keepe vs free. both sleepes.

div.stage: Enter sir Richard Lee, and his men

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: A murder closely done and in my ground?
Search carefully, if any where it were,
This obscure thicket is the likeliest place.

sp.speaker: seruant.
sp.l: Sir I haue found the body stiffe with cold,
And mangled cruelly with many wounds.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Looke if thou knowest him, turne his body vp,
A lacke it is my son, my sonne and heire,
Whom two yeares since, I sent to Ireland,
To practise there the discipline of warre,
And comming home (for so he wrote to me)
Some sauage hart, some bloudy diuellish hand,
Either in hate, or thirsting for his coyne,
Hath here slucde out his bloud, vnhappy houre,
Accursed place, but most inconstant fate,
That hadst reserude him from the bullets fire,
And suffered him to scape the wood-karnes fury,
Didst here ordaine the treasure of his life,
(Euen here within the armes of tender peace,
And where security gate greatest hope)
To be consumde by treasons wastefull hand?
And what is most afflicting to my soule,
That this his death and murther should be wrought,
Without the knowledge by whose meanes twas done,

sp.speaker: 2 seru.
sp.l: Not so sir, I haue found the authors of it,
See where they sit, and in their bloudy fistes,
The fatall instruments of death and sinne.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Iust iudgement of that power, whose gracious eie,
Loathing the sight of such a hainous fact,
Dazeled their senses with benumming-sleepe,
Till their vnhallowed treachery were knowne:
Awake ye monsters, murderers awake,
Tremble for horror, blush you cannot chuse,
Beholding this inhumane deed of yours.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What meane you sir to trouble weary soules,
And interrupt vs of our quiet sleepe?

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Oh diuellish! can you boast vnto your selues
Of quiet sleepe, hauing within your hearts
The guilt of murder waking, that with cries
Deafes the lowd thunder, and sollicites heauen,
With more than Mandrakes shreekes for your offence?

sp.speaker: Lady Old.
sp.p: What murder? you vpbraid vs wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Can you deny the fact? see you not heere,
The body of my sonne by you mis-done?
Looke on his wounds, looke on his purple hew:
Do we not finde you where the deede was done?
Were not your kniues fast closed in your hands?
Is not this cloth an argument beside,
Thus staind and spotted with his innocent blood?
These speaking characters, were nothing else
To pleade against ye, would conuict you both.
Bring them away, bereauers of my ioy,
At Hartford where the Sises now are kept,
Their liues shall answere for my sonnes lost life.

sp.speaker: Old castle
sp.p: As we are innocent, so may we speede.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.p: As I am wrongd, so may the law proceede. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter bishop of Rochester, constable of S. Albons, with sir Iohn of Wrotham, Doll his wench, and the Irishman in Harpooles apparell.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What intricate confusion haue we heere?
Not two houres since we apprehended one,
In habite Irish, but in speech, not so:
And now you bring another, that in speech
Is altogether Irish, but in habite
Seemes to be English: yea and more than so,
The seruant of that heretike Lord Cobham.

sp.speaker: Irishman
sp.l: Fait me be no seruant of the lord Cobhams,
Me be Mack Chane of Vlster.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Otherwise calld Harpoole of Kent, go to sit,
You cannot blinde vs with your broken Irish.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Trust me, my Lord Bishop, whether Irish,
Or English, Harpoole or not Harpoole, that
I leaue to be decided by the triall:
But sure I am this man by face and speech
Is he that murdred yong sir Richard Lee:
I met him presently vpon the fact,
And that he slew his maister for that gold,
Those iewells, and that chaine I tooke from him.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Well, our affaires doe call vs backe to London,
So that we cannot prosecute the cause
As we desire to do, therefore we leaue
The charge with you, to see they be conuaide
To Hartford Sise: both this counterfaite
And you sir Iohn of Wrotham, and your wench,
For you are culpable as well as they,
Though not for murder, yet for felony.
But since you are the meanes to bring to light
This gracelesse murder, you shall beare with you,
Our letters to the Iudges of the bench,
To be your friendes in what they lawfull may.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I thanke your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.p: So, away with them. exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gaoler and his man, bringing forth Old castle.

sp.speaker: Gaoler
sp.l: Bring forth the prisoners, see the court preparde,
The Iustices are comming to the bench.
So, let him stand, away, and fetch the rest. exeunt.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Oh giue me patience to indure this scourge,
Thou that art fountaine of that vertuous streame,
And though contempt, false witnes, and reproch
Hang on these yron gyues, to presse my life
As low as earth, yet strengthen me with faith,
That I may mount in spirite aboue the cloudes.
sp.stage: Enter Gaoler bringing in Lady Old-castle, and Harpoole.
sp.l: Here comes my lady, sorow tis for her,
Thy wound is greeuous, else I scoffe at thee.
What and poore Harpoole! art thou ith bryars too?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: I faith my Lord, I am in, get out how I can.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Say (gentle Lord) for now we are alone,
And may conferre, shall we confesse in briefe,
Of whence, and what we are, and so preuent
The accusation is commencde against vs?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What will that helpe vs? being knowne, sweete loue,
We shall for heresie be put to death,
For so they tearme the religion we professe.
No, if it be ordained we must die,
And at this instant, this our comfort be,
That of the guilt imposde, our soules are free.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Yea, yea my lord, Harpoole is so resolude,
I wreake of death the lesse, in that I die
Not by the sentence of that enuious priest
The Bishop of Rochester, oh were it he,
Or by his meanes that I should suffer here,
It would be double torment to my soule.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Well, be it then according as heauen please.

div.stage: Enter lord Iudge, two Iustices, Maior of Saint Albons, lord Powesse and his lady, and old sir Richard Lee: the Iudge and Iustices take their places.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Now M. Maior, what gentleman is that,
You bring with you, before vs and the bench?

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: The Lord Powes if it like your honor,
And this his Lady, trauelling toward Wales,
Who for they lodgde last night within my house,
And my Lord Bishop did lay search for such,
Were very willing to come on with me,
Lest for their sakes, suspition we might wrong.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: We crie your honor mercy good my Lord,
Wilt please ye take your place, madame your ladyship,
May here or where you will repose your selfe,
Vntill this businesse now in hand be past.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.l: I will withdraw into some other roome,
So that your Lordship, and the rest be pleasde.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: With all our hearts: attend the Lady there.

sp.speaker: Lord Po.
sp.l: Wife, I haue eyde yond prisoners all this while,
And my conceit doth tel me, tis our friend,
The noble Cobham, and his vertuous Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.l: I thinke no lesse, are they suspected trow ye
For doing of this murder?

sp.speaker: Lord Po.
sp.l: What it meanes,
I cannot tell, but we shall know anon,
Meane space as you passe by them, ask the question,
But do it secretly, you be not seene,
And make some signe that I may know your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.p: My Lord Cobham, madam? as she passeth ouer the stage by them.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: No Cobham now, nor madam as you loue vs,
But Iohn of Lancashire, and Ione his wife.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.l: Oh tel, what is it that our loue can do,
To pleasure you, for we are bound to you.

sp.speaker: Oldca.
sp.l: Nothing but this, that you conceale our names,
So gentle lady passe for being spied.

sp.speaker: Lady Po.
sp.p: My heart I leaue, to beare part of your griefe. exit,

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Call the prisoners to the barre: sir Richard Lee,
What euidence can you bring against these people,
To proue them guiltie of the murder done?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: This bloudy towell, and these naked kniues,
Beside we found them sitting by the place,
Where the dead body lay within a bush.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: What answer you why law should not proceed,
According to this euidence giuen in,
To taxe ye with the penalty of death?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: That we are free from murders very thought,
And know not how the gentleman was slaine.

sp.speaker: 1 Iust.
sp.p: How came this linnen cloth so boudy then?

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.l: My husband hot with trauelling my lord,
His nose gusht out a bleeding, that was it.

sp.speaker: 2 Iust.
sp.p: But wherefore were your sharpe edgde kniues vnsheathde?

sp.speaker: Lady Cob.
sp.p: To cut such simple victuall as we had.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Say we admit this answer to those articles,
What made ye in so priuate a darke nooke,
So far remote from any common path,
As was the thicke where the dead corpes was throwne?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Iournying my lord from London from the terme,
Downe into Lancashire where we do dwell,
And what with age and trauell being faint,
We gladly sought a place where we might rest,
Free from resort of other passengers,
And so we strayed into that secret corner.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: These are but ambages to driue of time,
And linger Iustice from her purposde end.
But who are these?

div.stage: Enter the Constable, bringing in the Irishman, sir Iohn of Wrotham, and Doll

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Stay Iudgement, and release those innocents,
For here is hee, whose hand hath done the deed,
For which they stand indited at the barre,
This sauage villaine, this rude Irish slaue,
His tongue already hath confest the fact,
And here is witnes to confirme as much.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.l: Yes my good Lords, no sooner had he slaine
His louing master for the wealth he had,
But I vpon the instant met with him,
And what he purchacde with the losse of bloud,
With strokes I presently bereau'de him of,
Some of the which is spent, the rest remaining,
I willingly surrender to the hands
Of old sir Richard Lee, as being his,
Beside my Lord Iudge, I greet your honor,
With letters from my Lord of Winchester. deliuers a letter.

sp.speaker: Lee
sp.l: Is this the wolfe whose thirsty throate did drinke
My deare sonnes bloud? art thou the snake
He cherisht, yet with enuious piercing sting,
Assaildst him mortally? foule stigmatike,
Thou venome of the country where thou liuedst,
And pestilence of this: were it not that law
Stands ready to reuenge thy crueltie,
Traitor to God, thy master, and to me,
These hands should be thy executioner.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Patience sir Richard Lee, you shall haue iustice,
And he the guerdon of his base desert,
The fact is odious, therefore take him hence,
And being hangde vntil the wretch be dead,
His body after shall be hangd in chaines,
Neare to the place, where he did act the murder.

sp.speaker: Irish.
sp.p: Prethee Lord shudge let me haue mine own clothes, my strouces there, and let me be hangd in a with after my cuntry, the Irish fashion. exit.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Go to, away with him, and now sir Iohn,
Although by you, this murther came to light,
And therein you haue well deseru'd, yet vpright law,
So will not haue you be excusde and quit,
For you did rob the Irishman, by which
You stand attained here of felony,
Beside, you haue bin lewd, and many yeares
Led a lasciuious vnbeseeming life.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Oh but my Lord, he repents, sir Iohn repents he will mend.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: In hope thereof, together with the fauour,
My Lord of Winchester intreates for you,
We are content you shall be proued.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: I thanke your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: These other falsly here, accusde, and brought
In perill wrongfully, we in like sort
Do set at liberty, paying their fees.

sp.speaker: Lord Po.
sp.l: That office if it please ye I will do,
For countries sake, because I know them well,
They are my neighbours, therefore of my cost,
Their charges shall be paide.

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.l: And for amends,
Touching the wrong vnwittingly I haue done,
There are a few crownes more for them to drinke. giues them a purse.

sp.speaker: Iudge.
sp.l: Your kindnes merites praise sir Richard Lee,
So let vs hence. exeunt all but Lord Powesse and Oldcastle.

sp.speaker: Lord Po.
sp.l: But Powesse still must stay,
There yet remaines a part of that true loue,
He owes his noble friend vnsatisfide,
And vnperformd which first of all doth bind me,
To gratulate your lordships safe deliuery,
And then intreat, that since vnlookt for thus,
We here are met, your honor would vouchsafe,
To ride with me to Wales, where though my power,
(Though not to quittance those great benefites,
I haue receiud of you) yet both my house,
My purse my seruants, and what else I haue,
Are all at your command, deny me not,
I know the Bishops hate pursues ye so,
As theres no safety in abiding here.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Tis true my Lord, and God forgiue him for it.

sp.speaker: Lord Po.
sp.l: Then let vs hence, you shall be straight prouided
Of lusty geldings, and once entred Wales,
Well may the Bishop hunt, but spight his face,
He neuer more shall haue the game in chace. exeunt.
